question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a new way of thinking about African American history in the United States. Most of the structure is I learned about more African American history through black literature, and I also learned how to think critically about thee readings. Lastly, I learned how to gain the confidence to lead discussion about some of this literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also learned how to write about those questions while trying to answer them with a very limited word limit. Lastly, we had to lead a discussion, so I learned how to create intellectual and complex questions according to a text we were asked to read.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

3. The Nasher Museum's display of Black art and how it can be used as a resource for students in various ways

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class discussions were very helpful because they showed what parts of the books we read were the most significant to the class and which may have been misunderstood. There were some passages of text that I didn't understand when I initially read them, and the class input was helpful later on.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed listening to Professor Lubiano's lectures—she is one of the most intelligent and well-spoken professors I've ever met—and has a profound ability to integrate the theory and literature we encounter in class. I also appreciated how she elevated "colloquial" knowledge to the level of the academy (asking us, for example, to include hypertext and internet sources within our final paper, or bringing up the example of the online forum on dragons). This is something I haven't seen any other professor do before, and as someone who has a few reservations about the nature of literature and the academy, something I didn't take for granted. Additionally, I enjoyed the format of having one or two students come up with discussion questions for each work we talked about in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The environment of the class felt more like a lecture, however, I appreciated the assignments which would focus on each individual's questions and understanding of the literature within the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really appreciated the diversity of the literature (and film) we encountered in class, as well as how intentional Professor Lubiano was about, as the title gestured to, Black speculative fiction in the context of selected others. I was initially expecting the course only to include Black Speculative Fiction, but I found that the inclusion of authors (both their fiction and theoretical work) from other natal communities was incredibly enriching to my understanding.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Lubiano is incredibly caring and insightful, and that comes with the cost of occasionally not being able to understand her tangents. Her brain works in powerful and unusual ways, and you can get a ton out of the class if you attempt to keep up.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was an extremely tedious course, but the work was minimal (3 short essays and one longer final paper). Professor Lubiano is very intelligent but often struggles with conveying information, so her lectures are quite disjointed and convoluted. Many times, she would leave no room for students to speak during the entire 2.5-hour class. There was a lot of assigned reading, but, as stated, we rarely discussed them and were instead lectured at about them for 2.5 hours. And, as the lectures were so hard to follow anyway, it felt like doing the readings was pointless. If you’re looking to learn something about literature, look elsewhere. There are many other excellent professors in the English department with significantly more engaging methods of instruction.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's an amazing class, but get ready to do a lot of reading and writing!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I have a hard time describing it, but I am now better at seeing the structure of the world as it exists, primarily for her attention to affinity, feeling, and the ways in which structures or people come into being or power. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to analyze film beyond the plot, focusing on visual elements like framing and color to understand deeper meanings. I also gained insight into how Chinese cinema reflects regional and historical shifts, especially through directors like Jia Zhangke. Lastly, I learned to appreciate minimalism and silence in film as powerful storytelling tools. Before this class, I had no experience with film analysis, and, quite frankly, did not appreciate them to the level that I do now.

response_text:

I liked that the quizzes were on paper.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The drop-2 grading policy for writing assignments and quizzes was highly encouraging, and took a lot of the pressure off of experimentation. The course highly values originality and the ability to not only extrapolate value from the material but meaningfully synthesize it with other topics, develop an argument, and learn the rhetoric to portray that argument effectively. Göknar is very approachable and helpful and when I felt lost in the course (which was somewhat frequent), he always took time to point me int he right direction.

I learned how Islam was reinterpreted in modern contexts, particularly in a black empowerment light.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned about some aspects of queer theory, how to engage with queer media thoughtfully, and how to better articulate my thoughts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about queer cinema and about the context in which the films we watched were created.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Developed ability to analyze film, engaged with content that strengthened queer theoretical background and gave me practice reading cinematographic queerness.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was exposed to a wide variety of popular queer media, most of which I had not seen yet and was grateful to have experienced now. I think I got much more accustomed to film theory and ideas, and writing critically about films, since I’d never taken a film centric class prior to this one.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze cinema using the lens of queer theory, how to create a zine, and how to write about movies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of new perspectives about queerness and how it is portrayed in media. I learned how to critically analyze LGBTQ media on my own, and through experiencing queer media learned a lot of queer history

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about a few different film techniques that can be used to generate various feelings for the viewer. I also learned about the history of expression and repression in queer media, particularly in the context of the Hays code. I also learned how different people define and express their identity, which I felt that the discord posts facilitated.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Different points to start on when analyzing a film. 
2. How to combine literature work into film analysis
3. Comparison between films

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Archer did a wonderful job facilitating fruitful discussions in class and on Discord. I liked the format -- having a discussion and then watching a film was a great way to proceed through the class and keep us interested.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed hearing about other people's opinions of the films during class discussions. The discord responses were a good way to reflect on the assigned films and readings. My favorite part of the course was probably the midterm (zine), which was really fun to make.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes, the structure of the course was fantastic. To split screenings and discussion both between class and home kept me engaged with the material throughout the week and fostered reflection. Discussions in class often left me with new insights and rarely dragged on for too long.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that discussion was very open, and that Professor Boyette encouraged us to explore alternative methods of thinking about film, such as making zines and creating our own film proposal, which I found much more interesting than just writing a midterm/final essay.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the Discord-hosted forum, for one because it felt like an actual discussion space due to it not being hosted on an academic site, and secondly because I loved hearing what my classmates were thinking about the movies we watched since we couldn’t discuss immediately after the showing. I also loved the midterm zine and this should definitely be kept!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I enjoyed the fact that we had screenings in class instead of having to do them at home. It's very easy to get in the habit of just putting things on 2x speed when working asynchronously, so it was good to actually be required to sit and be engaged with the film during lecture hours. I discovered some great films in this class, some of my favorites being Tangerine, The Watermelon Woman, Pink Flamingos, etc

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you’re wanting to explore queer film and film theory, take the course! It’s a great introduction. As a queer individual who grew up not really engaging in queer histories and popular culture, I enjoyed getting to understand queer lived experiences through this angle.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you’re queer and you love movies, you’ll love this class!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this class. I think there is something to be gained for people with every level of exposure to film study and GSF study.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a great introduction to the world of film in general with diverse topics and films. Many of the films beautifully portray the queer experience and offer a starting point for important conversations within the community. You don't need to know anything about films or LGBTQ+ culture before taking this class, as it is all covered and addressed week by week. If you are looking for a class to fill an empty slot, I highly recommend this one!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great course with very interesting components and will provide you with many different aspects to look into the history, development, and categories of queer film

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-Aspects of films and media that I can identify implicit meanings of, specifically for queer implications
-Cultural and historical background and context for all of the films we watched, going from the 1920s onward and giving in-depth overview of queer history and representation in film
-New insights about what it means for films to be campy, queer, avant-garde, experimental, and everything in between. I really felt connected to the films and queer history
-New insights about a variety of cultural backgrounds and how people of different races, ages, global locations, etc. experience queerness and problems that queer communities face at the intersection of identities

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:

-Projects in class encouraged creativity and embracing queer culture and freedom of expression

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to look at movies with a more insightful and critical lens. There is so much more to films than just were they enjoyable. It was cool to learn about the framing and mise-en-scene of movies and how they're carefully crafted.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to watch and analyze films from a critical perspective, for example, how the context behind the film affected its production and the use of film elements (framing, mise en scene).
I also learned how to write analytical essays that compare between films, and how to better understand how genre affects the stylistic and semantic elements of film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have developed skills to analyze films more critically and holistically. I have also improved upon my written reflection abilities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the construct of a variety of different film genres including the western, sci-fi, thriller, and melo-drama. To heighten the analysis of these films, I also learned about elements important for how films are created such as mise-en-scene and framing. Lastly, I had to think critically to compare films within the same genre construct weekly.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to watch films with a critical eye, the different aspects of analyzing film through writing, and I learned about several different genre conventions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The current discussion and relevance of Ecomedia. It helped me expand my conception of media and its relationship with the environment and ecological issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better theoretical understanding of eco-media as a scholarly field, I had access to a summary of discussions concerning Ecology in the Humanities (such as the Anthropocene and derived concepts), I had access to case studies of art and media related to Ecological discussions, especially in China.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Very interesting articles, learned a lot from these readings. For example, "bare life", "power relationship".
The professor offers many profound films that discuss ecological issues in society. Analyze and discuss these movies in conjunction with reading.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I first learned what eco-media is, and what topics and methods eco-media covers. Secondly, I learned how to analyze scenes in a film that a director might be inclined to express. Third, I learned a conceptual framework from academic film reviews that can provide a deeper perspective for interpreting films related to environmental issues, such as global waste, mining industries, toxicity, manufactured landscape, and multispecies entanglement.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how different groups of people embrace eco-media as an approach to environmental criticism. Most importantly, I learned how varied directors portrayed manifestations of environmental degradation differently to approach the questions concerning agency and subalternity. 
2. I learned methods of analyzing not only eco-media works but also its materiality. Specifically, I learned about how they are produced, circulated and consumed. More importantly, I learned how the production and circulation of media could impose secondary toxic effects on the environment.
3. The course content also helps me to learn to situate and historicize different forms of precarity regarding one's embeddedness within global capitalism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned not only how to further analyze the writing of Nobel prize winners themselves, but also how to unpack the historical and social contexts behind them. By covering a new work of literature every week, we got a sense of the type of writing that earns this sort of recognition, in addition to an understanding of the breadth of form and topics that have been awarded the Nobel Prize.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading a book a week and analysis readings critically, it also helped with writing literary texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read cross-textually and consider themes that persisted across all texts. I learned how to place texts in their historical, political, social environments. I learned how to bring in philosophical ideologies when reading texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, analytical writing, literary criticism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critical Analysis of Literature: One of the most significant skills I developed in this course was the ability to critically analyze literary works. We learned to dissect complex texts, examining their themes, narrative structures, character development, and use of language. This involved not only understanding the surface-level content but also interpreting the deeper meanings and societal implications. 
Historical and Cultural Contextualization: The course enhanced my ability to place literary works within their historical and cultural contexts. This skill was crucial in understanding the significance of each author's work in their time and its lasting impact.
Diverse Perspectives and Empathetic Understanding: Engaging with a broad range of authors from different cultural backgrounds greatly enhanced my ability to appreciate diverse perspectives. This course encouraged an empathetic approach to literature, urging us to understand and respect viewpoints and experiences different from our own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more analytically about a literary text. I improved my skills in close reading, synthesizing my thoughts, and identifying themes that run throughout a piece.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Creative thinking and critical analysis

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Historical and cultural context in which prominent works of the 20th century were written. 
- Techniques and frames with which we can analyze literary texts 
- Practice writing interpretive essays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course provided extremely interesting insights into the literary "greats" of the 20th century and into different cultures. I learned about the roles of bystanders/authors and the many tragedies that have shaped certain countries and communities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to how to relate history with personal experiences, close reading analysis, and the more historical background on the communism and colonization.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned so much. We learned a lot about history and philosophy, and I think our explorations of so many texts in such depth made me a better critical reader and writer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our discussions of Nobel Prize-winning literature let us view these works through the lens of the author's personal background, the communal context in which they lived, and the goal with which they wrote—and of course, touched on colonialism as a recurrent theme in all the novels, short stories, dramas, poetry, and essays! I thought that although it was primarily lecture-based, I still felt that I was engaged and interested in each topic covered.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned a lot about durham local food themes. Strengthened my conversational french and confidence presenting. Developed my understanding on the importance and ways that food influences our lives

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Much better understanding of food systems, Casual French speaking skills, teamwork

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me to appreciate food and where it comes from so much! I learnt about foodways and the importance of asking where ingredients for your food are sourced from. I also learnt the value in eating locally and interacting with local producers (like we did during our visits to Loaf and Sweets by Shayda). This course helped me feel a lot more connected to the Durham community, and has inspired me to think deeply about food and what it means to me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about food in other cultures, and about sustainability in farming. On our field trips, I learned how to make bread and pastries, and how to compost.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned a lot about the implications of eating locally and the cultural aspects reflected within food

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about footways, food systems, and how we interact with it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Practiced my French; learned about food systems, Foodways, the multi-faceted definition of "locality," and a lot more about the food culture of Durham.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Mme. Florand is the best teacher I have had at Duke. All of the assignments were engaging, and I knew why I was doing them. The service component was amazing. I liked the homework structure with discussions and forums. And i enjoyed the discourse in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We had many on field activities, and community engagements. I loved them, the system of the class should be kept the same.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I truly enjoyed this class because of how enthusiastic and kind our instructor was. She supplemented our readings with numerous experiential learning components, and the classroom was always extremely interactive. I also really appreciated that she made the classroom a comfortable environment to speak in. Even though my French is no where near perfect, I felt confident expressing myself in this class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the field trips and the projects where we got to bring in food for our classmates. I also enjoyed the wine tasting with the sommelier.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Florand was always very welcoming and the service learning aspects were a great way to learn

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the best way was scheduling the community work days, but also inviting speakers from other countries so we can get a better, more well rounded view of the material we were trying to discuss.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Loved the class field trips -- would definitely recommend keeping them, especially the Root Causes one. I also really enjoyed the "Partager un plat" assignments because It helped me learn both about new foods and also more about my classmates!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The selection of content that we were to review, the many different ways we engaged with the content, and the respect that Mme. Florand had for each of her students made this one of my most stimulating classes. We would have field trips or people come in from the community to speak to use and engage in conversations about french culture and food and eating locally. Instead of just reading about these concepts, we heard from the people who's lives are dedicated to these causes first hand.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The conflict between ideological loyalty and material harm prevention—whether in the regulation of AI-generated disinformation or in the defense of capitalist market structures—reveal the same pattern repeats: ideology-first positions prioritize abstract principles even when faced with clear evidence of harm, while material-first positions seek to address concrete damage, even at the cost of ideological purity. This essay will show how this underlying dynamic shapes both debates over AI regulation and the longstanding capitalism versus communism controversy.In the current debates surrounding AI regulation, especially around deepfake imagery and disinformation, the divide is sharp. Anti-regulation advocates adopt an ideology-first stance, prioritizing principles of free speech absolutism and market autonomy. Organizations like the Cato Institute frame any attempt to regulate AI content as a slippery slope to censorship or dangerous government overreach. Similarly, the narrative that "innovation must be free from interference" dismisses the material harms caused by AI disinformation — such as manipulated election outcomes, voter suppression, and the erosion of public trust. The underlying ideological commitment to liberty and free market operation remains firm even in the face of mounting evidence that AI technologies, left unchecked, can profoundly destabilize democratic institutions.Conversely, pro-regulation advocates adopt a material-first position, focusing not on preserving ideological purity, but on minimizing measurable harm. They prioritize policies like mandatory watermarking of AI-generated media, platform accountability for disinformation campaigns, and transparency requirements for algorithmic content distribution. Their arguments are grounded in concrete evidence: AI models have exacerbated biases in hiring, deepened misinformation flows, and enabled new forms of exploitation and surveillance. Rather than focusing on deontological arguments about abstract rights, material-first proponents insist that preventing real-world damage must take precedence, even if it entails some limitations on absolute free expression or market freedom.This structure mirrors the capitalism versus communism debate throughout the twentieth century. Capitalist apologetics frequently operated from an ideology-first perspective, framing free markets and competition as "natural" forces immune to political critique. Ideologies of meritocracy — that wealth and success reflect personal virtue — mystified systemic inequalities, obscuring the exploitation and structural violence embedded in global capitalism. Even as ecological collapse, labor precarity, and extreme wealth gaps became more visible, defenders of market ideology dismissed these harms as "externalities" rather than evidence of fundamental flaws. Their loyalty remained not to empirical outcomes but to the abstract sanctity of market competition.On the other side, critiques of capitalism — including socialist and communist thought — adopt a material-first approach. These critiques prioritize harm reduction: alleviating poverty, protecting ecological systems, ensuring workers' rights, and reducing systemic inequality. They are less concerned with preserving the ideological purity of economic "freedom" and more concerned with minimizing the tangible suffering produced by capitalist systems. Whether through labor protections, wealth redistribution, or environmental regulation, material-first critiques demand that abstract ideals yield when faced with material devastation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In the traditional model of ideological control, elites dominate mental production by distributing first-order ideological content: direct messages about what is true, good, or desirable. However, this is no longer the only — or even the primary — mechanism. In the contemporary world, not only does mental production distribute first-order ideology, but also the enforcement of second-order ideology additionally distributes first-order ideology. Seemingly neutral frameworks like "free speech," "anti-misinformation," and "anti-hate speech" are second-order ideologies that not only prescribe how the media should distribute first-order content but universalize first-order values through their enforcement. Thus, the public inherits first-order ideologies not only from the media itself but derive them from universal prescriptions of what kinds of communication are deemed legitimate.Consider "misinformation" enforcement. During the Cold War, elites not only flooded the media with anti-communist messages; they also framed sympathy toward communism itself as "misinformation" or "subversion." Thus, communism being bad was not only simply conveyed through the arguments the media made, but through ruling the discussion of alternatives as inherently illegitimate and a form of misinformation. In this context, "misinformation" as a second-order ideology was a direct extension of a first-order ideological battle: capitalism versus communism.In today's technocratic context, however, "misinformation" serves a different second-order function. The contemporary enforcement of "misinformation" on the surface seems to be a simple second-order filter for accuracy. However, such a filter spreads a universalist belief in objective truth — the idea that there exists a singular, recognizable reality that must be protected and disseminated for the sake of social cohesion and progress. Through this enforcement, public life becomes organized around a metaphysics of universal objectivity, where being properly informed is valued above all else.The antithesis of this is free speech absolutism. Media and education have long glorified individual liberty, often portraying censorship as synonymous with tyranny. The enforcement of free speech absolutism — treating any regulation of speech as dangerous — quietly installs this ideological lesson as a universal framework: that freedom is valued above all else, even at the expense of others' feelings, social cohesion, or truth itself. In this framework, we value our freedom over information integrity, emotional safety, and democratic stability, perpetuating the first-order libertarian ideal without openly stating it.Similarly, anti-hate speech policies reveal how second-order frameworks distribute first-order ideology. Modern pluralistic societies emphasize the protection of marginalized groups, and content celebrating diversity and inclusion is everywhere. The enforcement of "anti-hate" regulations carries this deep implication: that emotional harm and subjective feelings deserve institutional protection. Thus, anti-hate enforcement teaches that our feelings should be valued — that emotional safety is not merely a private concern, but a political and communicative standard that reshapes the public sphere.In each case, second-order enforcement distributes first-order ideology by naturalizing its assumptions about legitimacy, safety, harm, and truth. What appears as neutral procedural management — combating misinformation, protecting speech, ensuring emotional safety — is in fact the continuation of elite interests by other means. Thus, mental production is no longer simply about distributing beliefs; it is about embedding frameworks that structure the conditions of belief themselves. Today's ideological domination operates not only on the level of what we think, but even more profoundly on what kind of relationship to truth, harm, and freedom we are allowed to have.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the post-war discussion and knowledge surrounding the Holocaust and WWII in Germany. It was something that I had never learned about; I always learned about the Holocaust, but never the intellectual aftermath. I also learned some film methods and techniques, since this class was an ALP and we watched a decent amount of movies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed a range of knowledge, skills, and insights that have significantly enriched my understanding of the subject matter. One specific thing I learned was the importance of critical thinking and analysis. Through various assignments and class discussions, I honed my ability to evaluate arguments, assess evidence, and identify logical fallacies, enabling me to approach complex issues with a more discerning eye. Additionally, I gained a deeper appreciation for the power of effective communication. Whether it was through written assignments and class discussions, I learned how to articulate my ideas clearly and persuasively, tailoring my message to different audiences and contexts. Lastly, this course exposed me to diverse perspectives and challenged my preconceived notions. By engaging with classmates from various backgrounds and exploring different viewpoints, I developed a greater sense of empathy and cultural awareness, fostering a more inclusive and open-minded way of thinking. Overall, these three specific learnings—critical thinking, effective communication, and embracing diversity—have not only enhanced my academic abilities but also equipped me with invaluable skills for navigating the complexities of the world beyond the classroom.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- This course over-delivered in terms of intellectual history; aside from familiarity with first-generation Frankfurt School thinkers, I now feel more comfortable embarking on studies of earlier German philosophy mainstays--namely Kant and Hegel. 
- The asking for questions and then incorporating answers into lecture was a pedagogical masterclass. Generally, the pedagogical decisions seemed well-reasoned in what seemed like a difficult classroom (various backgrounds and interests).
- I feel like my analytic rigor in reading philosophic text has been strengthened, in a strictly logical sense, a historicist sense, and on the level of the form of the argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This course was very enriching and allowed me to develop several important skills and insights: 
1) Exploration of Austrian Postwar Literature and Film: I gained a deep understanding of four major Austrian writers and filmmakers—Thomas Bernhard, Elfriede Jelinek, Michael Haneke, and Ulrich Seidl—whose works are foundational to postwar cultural and literary criticism in Austria.
2) Close Reading and Film Analysis: I improved my ability to engage in close reading and film analysis, emphasizing how to critically unpack texts and visual narratives in relation to broader social and cultural contexts.
3) Understanding Representations of Violence: I explored how graphic depictions of violence can serve as tools for education and enlightenment, pushing myself to remain open-minded about the purpose and impact of such representations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained exposure to a variety of Austrian films that I might not have encountered otherwise, broadening my understanding of Austrian film culture and its unique themes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was highly interested in breaking down the notion of a Eurocentric Humanistic ideal due to the nature of the course design, i.e. transgressive thinkers. However, I learnt that often in academia, one has to bite the bullet and decide what battles to fight. As such I learnt to disengage from arguments that did not give me back fruitful ideas and were unproductive to thinking critically about the issues the artists' work that was the primary material in the course was trying to do. The actual work was often buried in the discussions about the artists themselves and the participants were not asked to refrain from make universal statements about the literary or film-studies based values expressed in the works. I learnt that when the discussion becomes performative, I must quietly save my labor for when I have the intellectual and emotional energy. I enjoyed quite a few of the readings, both primary and secondary, but found that the discussions were often overshadowed by manspreading in the workplace, an issue often unaddressed in the graduate seminar, a workspace often disguised as solely a classroom. Lastly, and on a positive note, I learnt how to identify textual evidence to dialectically decipher the place a given text occupies in the literary history as visible from the contemporary moment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learnt how to theorize my interpretation of a text based on a close reading instead of using theoretical lenses.

response_text: Close readings, discourse on humanism in pre-war Austria, and film/image analysis

response_text: I definitely got better at close readings!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The overall learning environment was positive, and the course structure effectively supported my learning:* Student-Led Discussions: I appreciated the collaborative approach, as students leading parts of the discussion fostered engagement and new perspectives.
* Weekly Discussion Posts: Writing weekly posts allowed me to engage deeply with the materials, and I appreciated that the instructor thoughtfully read and provided feedback on all posts.
* Instructor Engagement: The instructor created an encouraging atmosphere for intellectual exploration.However, I think the discussions could benefit from integrating the weekly posts more directly into the class conversations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment, I appreciated the instructor's openness and flexibility, which created a welcoming space for discussion. The weekly Canvas responses were particularly effective in fostering engagement and reflection, and I think this component should be kept for future classes. However, I would suggest incorporating more structured guidance from the instructor, as well as adding theoretical background and close readings to provide a stronger foundation for analyzing the films. These additions would enhance the learning experience by balancing discussion with deeper context and analysis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professsor-instructor was highly amenable to being flexible about the primary textual materials under study in this class, especially with regard to the sensitivity of some participants and an incident that left many shook beyond performative solidarity with a participant new to the program. Moreover, the professor-instructor was kind about my own medical condition related to psychiatric health and did not hold it against me when I had to retreat from energetic participation into passive note-taking mode. I did not feel pressure to partake in any opinion-based consensus creation when the loudest members of the seminar were doing their usual think-out-loud discussions. I think the best part of this course was the discussion posts where the value-systems of each participants may be seen through close analysis of their writing styles and philosophical standpoints.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course was intellectually engaging, but there is room for improvement in the selection of secondary readings: Some texts were excellent (I particularly enjoyed the Rita Felski reading), but others were less effective due to unclear writing or arguments (e.g., Ahmed, Berlant, Nelson). The syllabus could have included foundational texts like Susan Sontag’s "On Photography" and "Looking at War," which were mentioned in class but not assigned. These could have enriched our discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made this class stimulating was the exposure to a range of Austrian films that I wouldn’t have encountered otherwise. However, it could have been more intellectually stimulating with a stronger theoretical foundation and more guided analysis. Incorporating close readings of the texts, deeper engagement with key concepts, and connecting these ideas more explicitly to the films would have enhanced the intellectual depth. Additionally, balancing open discussions with structured input from the instructor could make the class more engaging and thought-provoking. One area for improvement would be including more trigger warnings and regularly checking in on students' mental health, as the nature of the films often addressed challenging and sensitive topics.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: If the women were encouraged to speak more by asking the men to pipe down sometimes. I would have loved to see more decolonial thought on humanism as an exclusionary method to control humans and their poetic abilities as a member of the planet on a continuum with other forms of life and the material world that sustains them, rather than the notion of humans as elevated beings in control over the material reality upon which they are parasitic. far from being nihilistic, this poetic idea of a human as creative and trangressive rather than ascriptive and normative could have been the impetus for more stimulating and self-degrandizing set of discussions rather than 'redemption' as the limit of thought in the secularized versions of a Euro-Christian humanism.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are 3 "formal" writings which are only 3-4 full pages and 3-4 "informal writings" which are 2-3 paragraphs each (and a final reflection paper). You are allowed to "re-use" content from your informal writings to help guide your formal writings, in fact they are set up to prepare you for the formal writing. So really not too bad at all in terms of workload. Readings, on average, take no more than 3 hours per week.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically think and explore different academic texts varying from more digestible personal stories to dense academic texts. I have learned a lot about trans theory, critical theory, and also feminist studies as a whole. Also being able to engage in discussion is a skill I have learned more of. Learning how to write academic papers as well as answer to larger prompts that aren't looking for a specific answer but allow you to develop your own opinion and learn how to write arguments and provide evidence for that is a great skill I have learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Understanding of what the field of trans studies is
What affects are and how that is helpful for analysis
The importance of forcing ideas and concepts from today onto experiences from the past

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class gave me a new perspective on neoliberal hyper focus on identity and the purification of those categories, like cis and trans. It also gave me a new way of thinking about the role of the state in the creation and maintenance of things like sex and race, and also how medicolegal processes formed those as inseparable identifications. It was also really interesting to learn about non normative gendered subjects in Weimar/Nazi Germany and   (post) dictatorship Argentina and how fascist persecution is not homogeneous and relies in part on economic utility to the state.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned:
1) How "trans" goes beyond just individuals that identify as transgender (and how this conceptualization of transgender as relegated to personal identity is a more recent idea, and may not be how trans actually functions in the world today)
2) How biological sex is a more complicated and political topic than a previously thought, especially (but not limited to) how it and its relation to gender are racialized
3) How to synthesize and congeal my thoughts on a complicated, often confusing topic into an essay

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Introduction to a massive range of ideas within feminist theory, and the ability to critically discuss the works with humility and curiosity. Also, all of us got to participate in a world-famous conference on feminist theory!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Professor Nash surveyed the many, often conflicting, ways that (Black) feminisms have understood sexuality, gender, the university, law, identity, form, and beauty. Genealogies of feminisms—Professor Nash asks us to attend to the plurality of theoretical feminist frameworks—too often narrate its development through the contributions of white women, eliding the work of Black, third world, and indigenous feminists. Professor Nash corrects this omission.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Knowledge of Black feminism and it’s archives/epistemologies
2. The legal basis and majors legal scholars that underpin a lot of historical and contemporary feminist theory
3. Knowledge of different movements within feminist theory, e.g Standpoint Theory, Transnational Feminism, etc

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Nash is an exemplary pedagogue. She began each seminar by inviting us to each pose a question about the materials at hand, then deftly facilitated our conversation around these inquiries. She insisted we pay attention to the nitty gritty: to the context of the theorizations, to their forms of articulation, and to the unspoken intellectual currents. She challenged us to stay with what we found most challenging rather than deflect or arrive to some facile consensus.

And I liked how we oriented class around questions that we prepared before class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We read the entirety of The Divine Comedy, as well as the Vita Nuova and some supplements, so I learned quite a bit about Dante himself, as well as the political, theological, and philosophical environment in which he was situated compared to his own ideology. I learned how to analyze different translations of the text side-by-side, how to critique commentaries, and how to find relevant parallels between the different cantica. I also learned how to express all of this in writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned to read intently and read with purpose, clarifying the poem as I went through and engaging in critical discussions with my peers. Ultimately, my essays allowed me to exercise my knowledge on the poem and deepened my understanding every single time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof Eisner is one of my favorite professors at Duke. He is one of the most knowledgeable Dantean scholars out there, and his enthusiasm about Dante is infectious. His slides are so well-curated and he has so many random fun facts, e.g. about Virgil's pesto recipe on the US dollar bill. I thought the reading assignments were well-paced for the most part. The midterm was mostly fair passage identification and some factual information (expecting the final to be similarly fair). The papers were actually quite fun to write because we could choose to write about any translations, parallels, and commentaries we thought were most intriguing, i.e. there was a lot of free rein. The group activities, like the in-class art project, were great. I enjoyed the guest lecturer as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Martin Eisner elevated my learning experience of Dante's Divine Comedy through his energetic personality and thought-provoking insights into a rather esoteric poem. He elucidated a lot of thoughts I had coming in when I briefly read about 12 cantos. He forced us to grapple with many dimensions of Dante's poem and challenged my many preconceived notions on love, free will, the existence of a soul, and the role of mentorship within life. I would love to keep the whole presence of Professor Eisner within the course as I cannot imagine a more suitable professor to guide us through the dark wood that is the Spring semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dante's Divine Comedy is not just a story about a pilgrim who struggles to reach a heavenly paradise with Virgil as his guide, but rather leverages his writing to put the reader in an oasis chock-full of his own intimate thoughts regarding love, free will, the divinity of God. He is not afraid to step outside orthodox boundaries to go after people he doesn't like. Dante Alighieri freely and frequently brandishes his ire against 14th century ecclesial figures and put them through heart-wrenching methods of suffering. This coupled with an acute sense of self-awareness makes it hard to hate an exiled 14th century Italian man's charisma.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We became well-versed in modern European short fiction and the genre's many renowned authors, such as Kafka, Svevo, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Pirandello, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. We examined these works through the lens of five primary themes—animals, family and home, love, guilt, and the Holocaust—and determined how the stories can be categorized under one or more of these themes. We learned the distinction between modernism, post-modernism, existentialism, absurdism, communism, syndicalism, anarchism, and other ideologies in a literary context. We had the privilege of visiting the Rare Books library and picking works to analyze closely and the Nasher to look at the works of Chagall, Dali, and other relevant artists, as well as to do a compare/contrast essay on a short story and its film adaptation. These experiences allowed us to appreciate the important differences between different media: short vs. long-form fiction, final versions vs. galley proofs, film, and art. I also learned how to write a concise but effective paper, since our longest paper had a limit of three pages. Lastly, I learned how to appropriately analyze a short story by taking into consideration the plot, characters, author, and political/social implications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to analyze literary works in relation to their  historical context. I learned about surrealism in literature and I also learned about the impact of stylistic features and literary devices (as similitudes or imagery) on the reader.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze writing styles, word choice, and how to access the rarebook library.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think my analytical writing improved. I gained a better understanding and general knowledge of European literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Got better at analytical writing, was exposed to writers of Europe's past, and got better at interpretive reading.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained substantial knowledge of authors, works, and movements that are significant to European literature.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the way the course was structured, both the overarching structure of different themes for different groups of stories and the day-to-day structure of reading 1-5 short stories for class, coming to class to discuss in-depth, and then writing a short paper about a handful of these stories later on. I loved the unique opportunities the class had to offer, namely the Rare Books and Nasher visits and Francesca Magario guest lecture (I loved that lecture!). I loved the variety of papers: the close reading of a Kafka short short story, Rare Books object paper, animal research paper, and film and passage comparison essay. This is also the only humanities class in which I've had an exam, but I think it made sense to include it as an assessment because it forced me to stay on top of the readings (and come to class) and not just skim them. It meant I thoroughly read each story to learn the author's style and the story's influence. Professor Z is very insightful, prepared for class, engaging, and accommodating with deadlines, and she really shines when her students reciprocate an interest in the content. I was in a class with her last semester where the students were in general less engaged, which I think limited her teaching. This time around, most of the class came having done the readings with interesting takeaways/interpretations and ready to discuss, and this meant she could offer more as a professor as well. The professor and the students, in addition to the stories we read, made this class truly one of my favorites that I have taken at Duke.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class continuously operated in a space between discussion and lecture that I don't think was best. First off, it couldn't really operate as a discussion with there being 25 people in the class. I think breaking up classes, or parts of each class, into either lecture or discussion would be more engaging and let the material stick more. I think students would get more out of it that way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course if you can! It was one of my favorite classes that I have taken at Duke. The readings are both thought-provoking and entertaining, as are the in-class discussions we had about them. By the end of the course, you'll be able to say that you're well-versed in modern European short fiction authors like Kafka, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. You get to do some cool out-of-class excursions too, like to the Rare Books library and the Nasher. The professor is very knowledgeable, effectively facilitates class discussions, and is very accommodating with deadlines. Plus the papers are very short (max 3 pages). There is one exam where you have to match 12 or so quotes to their author/work and write about the immediate context and significance of the quote, but it is very doable if you do all the readings and come to class consistently. I genuinely have no criticisms of this class.

It's very easy to get in the habit of just putting things on 2x speed when working asynchronously, so it was good to actually be required to sit and be engaged with the film during lecture hours. I discovered some great films in this class, some of my favorites being Tangerine, The Watermelon Woman, Pink Flamingos, etc

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

The unique identities and experiences of my classmates and how that influenced their contributions to the class was also quite enriching.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you’re wanting to explore queer film and film theory, take the course! It’s a great introduction. As a queer individual who grew up not really engaging in queer histories and popular culture, I enjoyed getting to understand queer lived experiences through this angle.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a great introduction to the world of film in general with diverse topics and films. Many of the films beautifully portray the queer experience and offer a starting point for important conversations within the community. You don't need to know anything about films or LGBTQ+ culture before taking this class, as it is all covered and addressed week by week. If you are looking for a class to fill an empty slot, I highly recommend this one!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-Aspects of films and media that I can identify implicit meanings of, specifically for queer implications

-New insights about what it means for films to be campy, queer, avant-garde, experimental, and everything in between. I really felt connected to the films and queer history
-New insights about a variety of cultural backgrounds and how people of different races, ages, global locations, etc. experience queerness and problems that queer communities face at the intersection of identities

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically analyze global cultural studies in film, readings, and more. I learned how to build up my confidence and engage in meaningful discussion during class. I also learned how to use the terms everyday life, culture, globalization, and more in conversation and apply it to my observations of the world around me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I received wholesome knowledge on cultural studies. Structural, basic and useful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the skills I learned in this class was how to interpret a theoretical piece and how to analyze the theories made by certain theorists and connect that to my everyday life. A method of thinking that I developed was how to look at the micro/macro and how there are so many things in your personal life and outside of that that impact the way you live and interact with others. Another skill that I learned in this class was how to write a film preview and analyze and deconstruct films in a way that bring to life the deeper meanings and use that to connect it back to theorists we've read.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to analyze cultural objects and discuss films in a critical way 
2. I gained a deeper insight into critical theory & important theorists in the different schools
3. I got a lot better at writing and thinking!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Team work
2. Writing skill
3. Reading skill

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about the different theorists, Highmore, Adorno, Crary, Hall, Williams etc.
I learned how to theorize for myself based on these theorists. To develop my own voice in critical theory. 
I learned how to write to convey my own critical voice

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the very idea of what global cultural studies is,

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was fantastic and a wonderful introduction to the Global Cultural Studies and Theory (Literature) Major. I got a very introductory but in-depth understanding of what it means to do theory and I also learnt about its overlap and distinctions with cultural studies. I learnt about how to apply theory to cultural objects, often in my everyday life, and to think about both macro cultural movements (historical, economic, political, social) and micro cultural movements in my life through the lens of the theorists we studied.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to think about culture as everyday and ordinary rather than as confined to "high culture"
2. How to write critical analyses of films
3. Foundations in the fields of cultural studies and critical theory

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the instructors' constant engagement during class and their open lecture/seminar-style teaching helped me take notes and apply my knowledge into the class. I have never taken a seminar class before and I honestly liked it a lot more than just getting lectured to because I got to hear other classmate's ideas and opinions in addition to my teachers.
