I liked the way class was set up in the discussion mode where we would spend almost all of the class just talking and really diving into what we learned and it opened up my mind to being able to look at things in another way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The classroom atmosphere was very relaxed. Communicating with my classmates enhanced my communication and teamwork skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Splitting off into groups to discuss was very helpful for me. I really liked the general structure of the course as as well, beginning with the theorists and then moving into watching the fllms. I would keep all of this.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really loved how Professor Wiegman structured and taught this course. I believe she created a welcoming environment for critical exploration and thought. I liked how the class was divided into three sections -- in the first section, we learned the fundamental theory which would help guide our thinking as we explored specific cultural objects (including a novel and several films). I appreciated how much feedback Professor Wiegman gave for written assignments, and I truly felt like she was invested in my learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really loved the structure of the course - I personally really enjoyed first directly engaging with theory and then transitioning to the cultural object of sugar and blood and then trying to do cultural theory on film. I actually didn't expect to learn so much about film through this course, but I really feel that I gained a critical lens on that as film is something I haven't studied as much in my other Literature classes. All in all, I would keep the VARIETY of this course's learning material. I do think though that removing sugar and blood makes the course syllabus more coherent (and about theory and applying it to a cultural object) but I personally loved the historical memoir so I would prefer to retain that. Dr. Weigman is an amazing professor who knows how to engage every kind of learner in the class, so she did a fantastic job of asking questions to guide our thinking while making sure the conversation ensured both depth and breadth.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Reading theorists first then applying what we learned to films was helpful. The seminar format of the course also encouraged active thinking with peers. More often than not, I walked away from class feeling like I gained a new insight through the class discussion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to analyze film beyond the plot, focusing on visual elements like framing and color to understand deeper meanings. I also gained insight into how Chinese cinema reflects regional and historical shifts, especially through directors like Jia Zhangke. Lastly, I learned to appreciate minimalism and silence in film as powerful storytelling tools. Before this class, I had no experience with film analysis, and, quite frankly, did not appreciate them to the level that I do now.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to watch and analyze films from a critical perspective, for example, how the context behind the film affected its production and the use of film elements (framing, mise en scene).
I also learned how to write analytical essays that compare between films, and how to better understand how genre affects the stylistic and semantic elements of film.

response_text: This class was stimulating because it introduced me to new topics and points of view that I had not considered before. For example, I knew there were indigenous people in Mexico, but I had never thought to question how their status of indigeneity could change. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The small seminar class has helped facilitate various conversations that reflected some of the feelings of the students in the class. Majority of us have some sort of tie to Latin America and being able to talk about and relate to common experiences we have faced has been very validating. I also loved having the service aspect of the class. Getting out of the "Duke bubble" to engage with the Latinx Durham community was fulfilling and helped me create ties to a new community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned lots about different kinds of Latin American music, political movements, and the story behind words like Latinidad or ones that are equally or even more controversial like Malinche.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In the course, I developed critical thinking skills when examining labels and concepts like Latino and Latinidad. I learned about the history of the Latinx community in the United States and gained insight into issues like discrimination and assimilation that followed mass migration. I learned about the relevance of music in Latinx culture and thought about the many ways it can be used to express and explore culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Coming into the class, I had some pretty big assumptions about the general content of the class. At first, I didn't think the course was going to center on US Latinx studies; I thought it was
going to focus on the history of Latin American countries and how those become affected by US intervention. Personally, I truly enjoy the direction the course is going. Learning about the history
of Latinos in the US, their struggles, their legacy, is a rich topic that I had previously not had the resources to understand. I've always wanted to learn more about this but I've never really had
the impetus to do so. I think it is so interesting to talk about these historical events, like the Chicano movement or the labor strikes, and tell my friends about them. It's a part of history that
goes unnoticed and it's worthy of bringing up everyone once in a while during a conversation. Outside of that, I feel like this class has made me more conscious of the continual Latino
presence in the US and what people are doing to combat injustice. I've done research and learned about powerful organizations, both in North Carolina and my hometown of Miami. It's
amazing seeing that everywhere there are communities like these all fighting for visibility and justice. I gain a lot from the music component of the course, and connect it to other music classes I've
taken at Duke. It's interesting seeing the connection between how the music we study is composed and what the music is representing. Understanding the Chicano movement through
song is a beautiful way to look at history. A song I particularly found touching was "Urbano's song". It was by far one of the saddest songs I've heard this year, and I still listen to it in my
 spare time.More concisely I learned:
- How to analyze Latino history and research topics in Latino studies.
- How to make a community facing project 
- How service learning can be used to supplement a class as well as engage with the surrounding community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We became well-versed in modern European short fiction and the genre's many renowned authors, such as Kafka, Svevo, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Pirandello, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. We examined these works through the lens of five primary themes—animals, family and home, love, guilt, and the Holocaust—and determined how the stories can be categorized under one or more of these themes. We learned the distinction between modernism, post-modernism, existentialism, absurdism, communism, syndicalism, anarchism, and other ideologies in a literary context. We had the privilege of visiting the Rare Books library and picking works to analyze closely and the Nasher to look at the works of Chagall, Dali, and other relevant artists, as well as to do a compare/contrast essay on a short story and its film adaptation. These experiences allowed us to appreciate the important differences between different media: short vs. long-form fiction, final versions vs. galley proofs, film, and art. I also learned how to write a concise but effective paper, since our longest paper had a limit of three pages. Lastly, I learned how to appropriately analyze a short story by taking into consideration the plot, characters, author, and political/social implications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to analyze literary works in relation to their  historical context. I learned about surrealism in literature and I also learned about the impact of stylistic features and literary devices (as similitudes or imagery) on the reader.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze writing styles, word choice, and how to access the rarebook library.

response_text: I think my analytical writing improved. I gained a better understanding and general knowledge of European literature.

response_text: Got better at analytical writing, was exposed to writers of Europe's past, and got better at interpretive reading.

response_text: I gained substantial knowledge of authors, works, and movements that are significant to European literature.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the way the course was structured, both the overarching structure of different themes for different groups of stories and the day-to-day structure of reading 1-5 short stories for class, coming to class to discuss in-depth, and then writing a short paper about a handful of these stories later on. I loved the unique opportunities the class had to offer, namely the Rare Books and Nasher visits and Francesca Magario guest lecture (I loved that lecture!). I loved the variety of papers: the close reading of a Kafka short short story, Rare Books object paper, animal research paper, and film and passage comparison essay. This is also the only humanities class in which I've had an exam, but I think it made sense to include it as an assessment because it forced me to stay on top of the readings (and come to class) and not just skim them. It meant I thoroughly read each story to learn the author's style and the story's influence. Professor Z is very insightful, prepared for class, engaging, and accommodating with deadlines, and she really shines when her students reciprocate an interest in the content. I was in a class with her last semester where the students were in general less engaged, which I think limited her teaching. This time around, most of the class came having done the readings with interesting takeaways/interpretations and ready to discuss, and this meant she could offer more as a professor as well. The professor and the students, in addition to the stories we read, made this class truly one of my favorites that I have taken at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course if you can! It was one of my favorite classes that I have taken at Duke. The readings are both thought-provoking and entertaining, as are the in-class discussions we had about them. By the end of the course, you'll be able to say that you're well-versed in modern European short fiction authors like Kafka, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. You get to do some cool out-of-class excursions too, like to the Rare Books library and the Nasher. The professor is very knowledgeable, effectively facilitates class discussions, and is very accommodating with deadlines. Plus the papers are very short (max 3 pages). There is one exam where you have to match 12 or so quotes to their author/work and write about the immediate context and significance of the quote, but it is very doable if you do all the readings and come to class consistently. I genuinely have no criticisms of this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We read the entirety of The Divine Comedy, as well as the Vita Nuova and some supplements, so I learned quite a bit about Dante himself, as well as the political, theological, and philosophical environment in which he was situated compared to his own ideology. I learned how to analyze different translations of the text side-by-side, how to critique commentaries, and how to find relevant parallels between the different cantica. I also learned how to express all of this in writing.

I learned to read intently and read with purpose, clarifying the poem as I went through and engaging in critical discussions with my peers. Ultimately, my essays allowed me to exercise my knowledge on the poem and deepened my understanding every single time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof Eisner is one of my favorite professors at Duke. He is one of the most knowledgeable Dantean scholars out there, and his enthusiasm about Dante is infectious. His slides are so well-curated and he has so many random fun facts, e.g. about Virgil's pesto recipe on the US dollar bill. I thought the reading assignments were well-paced for the most part. The midterm was mostly fair passage identification and some factual information (expecting the final to be similarly fair). The papers were actually quite fun to write because we could choose to write about any translations, parallels, and commentaries we thought were most intriguing, i.e. there was a lot of free rein. The group activities, like the in-class art project, were great. I enjoyed the guest lecturer as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Martin Eisner elevated my learning experience of Dante's Divine Comedy through his energetic personality and thought-provoking insights into a rather esoteric poem. He elucidated a lot of thoughts I had coming in when I briefly read about 12 cantos. He forced us to grapple with many dimensions of Dante's poem and challenged my many preconceived notions on love, free will, the existence of a soul, and the role of mentorship within life. I would love to keep the whole presence of Professor Eisner within the course as I cannot imagine a more suitable professor to guide us through the dark wood that is the Spring semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's tough but a lot of fun and very insightful.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class!! Prof Eisner is an amazing professor with so much Dantean knowledge to offer, as well as fun facts that you definitely did not know. It's a lot of reading, but it is worth it. Exams are not too bad if you actually read the poem.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dante's Divine Comedy is not just a story about a pilgrim who struggles to reach a heavenly paradise with Virgil as his guide, but rather leverages his writing to put the reader in an oasis chock-full of his own intimate thoughts regarding love, free will, the divinity of God. He is not afraid to step outside orthodox boundaries to go after people he doesn't like. Dante Alighieri freely and frequently brandishes his ire against 14th century ecclesial figures and put them through heart-wrenching methods of suffering. This coupled with an acute sense of self-awareness makes it hard to hate an exiled 14th century Italian man's charisma.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! it was so fun and engaging

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE IT! Easily the best class I have taken at Duke thus far

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me to think critically about texts and analyze what is happening within them. I had not previously done this with a texts and I found it extremely interesting. I also learned a lot about fairy tales and different forms of analysis.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much in this class! From theories of fairy tale analysis to expanding my repertoire of the fairy tale genre - this class has been incredible.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the concepts of the evolution of storytelling, considered how sociopolitical climates influence stories, and examined the deeper meanings of fairytales.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned the history of fairy tales, from prior to the 16th century all the way to today. 
I learned how to analyze literature and media in a variety of different ways through a variety of different lenses.
I learned how to compare and contrast texts on a high level.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed critical and deeper understanding in fairy tales, and I learned how to interpret them with different perspectives such as historical view, feminism, psychoanalysis, media, etc. I also have an insight of the difference between collective-literature and authorship-literature, which is a very interesting topic that I've never heard of.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned the different scholarly approaches to fairy tales and how to analyze them using those theories
2) thinking about why fairy tales are structured or written the way they are: i.e. the depthlessness of fairy tales
3) how to skim articles

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to contextualize
I learned how to evaluate the structural aspects of a genre and classify works into genres while retaining space for ambiguity.
I learned how to compare and contrast the stances of different theorists, many of who wrote in different time periods

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned different lenses through which I can interpret fairy tales, learned about adaptation and oral storytelling, and learned about conventions to the fairy tale genre.

response_text: I learned how to analyze the structure of fairy tales and their effects on society in a number of lenses

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The syllabus and calendar for this course was well-written and helpful because it was so organized. In addition, I like how the readings we had to complete for each class were clearly labeled on Canvas. This class was also heavily discussion based, which was nice because it helped me push my thinking in new directions, and I got to hear my peers' thoughts and opinions, too.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked when we focused on the specific tales themselves and did deep dives into symbolism. I can't say that the instructor was engaging, however. I will say, the instructors were very helpful and open to answering questions about essays which I really appreciated.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The structure of the class was rather simple but effective. Read and reflect on content and come to class to share and develop ideas on that content. I love this format of class because it is rather free flowing and engaging. 
The parts I disliked the most were ones that stymied that format, particularly the work sheets. I feel as though giving specific content guidelines and 1 question to answer or 1 purpose in a group setting would have been just as effective and more interesting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
We had very many different forms of learning in class, it was not a slideshow reading class at all.
I would keep the going up to the board to review part because it is very helpful to be put on the spot to see how much you really understood/remember.
I would also keep the cinema element in one of the units we did as it helped tie everything we were reading with great films.
I liked that the quizzes were on paper.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The drop-2 grading policy for writing assignments and quizzes was highly encouraging, and took a lot of the pressure off of experimentation. The course highly values originality and the ability to not only extrapolate value from the material but meaningfully synthesize it with other topics, develop an argument, and learn the rhetoric to portray that argument effectively. Göknar is very approachable and helpful and when I felt lost in the course (which was somewhat frequent), he always took time to point me int he right direction.

Relative to other Duke courses, this is one of the most rewarding classes because it pushes you to be the best student you can be.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: More tangible skills were close reading of difficult philosophical passages and condensed, non-repetitive writing to synthesize course themes. Softer skills included thinking deeply about diction and syntax in literature, philosophical histories and connecting world-views of prominent 19th and 20th century European philosophers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close reading, philosophical thinking, analysis of literature, contemplation of existence. The scope of this course extends far beyond the classroom and I found myself thinking about it constantly.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-I learned about close analysis/reading, and how to construct an essay on just a few lines of text within a larger work. 
-I learned about the history of existential philosophy and how philosophers throughout time responded to the question of why we exist 
-I developed a stronger ability to read and comprehend difficult texts and the underlying themes

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had never heard of any of the philosophers we read in this class, and now I can say I have read Kierkegaard, Dostoyevsky, Nietzsche, Sartre, Beauvoir, and Beckett.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to engage with difficult texts an to not be intimidated by them. I learned to look for connections in ideas between texts and how to write to flesh these out.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: - Close reading of existentialist texts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a knowledge of eras, how those eras and the events during shaped the thoughts of philosophers during those times, and how those philosophers built thoughts on previous thoughts. And all of this knowledge was achieved through reading prominent, classic literature that we were able to learn how to interpret and interact with in order to gain philosophical insights from them. It was very interesting how each philosopher's circumstances drove their thinking, and how that thinking was able to be built upon and developed over time throughout many more eras and philosophers. And it was all about arguably the most important question one can ask themselves: what is the meaning of life? I was able to learn more about philosophers who thought there is an inherent meaning to life and what that meaning looked like to them, that there is not meaning to life, or that certain factors/experiences/mindsets could give one meaning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course has enabled me to develop my skills of analytical philosophy, close reading, and careful discussion skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The structure of the course was doing the readings beforehand, making a discussion post, and interacting with others' discussion posts. I thought this was helpful because I was able to experience the reading for myself, record my thoughts and connect it to my experiences or other readings, and then learn about how others interpreted the work. Then I was able to gain further insights in class afterwards about certain part of the texts. I thought this component of the course was very useful and facilitated my learning effectively, while still allowing for creativity of thought.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The themes of the course naturally lead to an intellectually stimulating environment. I think the discussion environment where students were thoughtful and engaged was extremely productive. I enjoyed how the professor encouraged multiple viewpoints and relied upon student contributions to discussions. I would keep the class as strictly no technology. To me, this helps with engagement in a discussion setting, especially when physical texts are required.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Readings are laid out in a very coherent way, such that each one both connects to prior themes and introduces something new. I was challenged by the philosophical ways of thinking provided by both Moi and my classmates. I think that the people who chose to take this class are very smart and have great ideas and want to learn about existentialism. This all contributes to very stimulating lectures and the feeling that I am discovering something new about the world and my own life.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I’m not a philosophy major, so a lot of concepts were completely new to me. Some of the readings were particularly challenging for me, but I learned so much and the topics and themes resonated with me. I was learning a new concept like the epistemological crisis or metaphysics every class and with every new reading, and I really enjoyed reading these texts. I feel as though I think differently after taking this class, like I’ve gained many new perspectives.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I appreciated the occasional historical aside that we learned about. It added a lot of context both to the philosophers and to their work.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The texts and the ideas presented were new to me and I understood a new set of ideas which was stiulating,

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was very stimulating because I feel like in a college environment like Duke where every student is so preoccupied with their productivity, efficiency, and career drive, it is easy to forget to just think and ponder on existence and our role in it. It was definitely a new way of thinking about literature that I have read or heard about, how to read closely on literature works, and how to approach existential questioning.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The range of existential texts covered in the course proved to be very fruitful in understanding the breadth and depth of existential thought beginning with Kierkegaard and leading to the postmodern era. I also enjoyed the lectures of this course and being able to learn from Professor Moi's knowledge on the subject alongside responses to questions from students.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a must-take! If you have any interest in existentialism or philosophy this course will depend your knowledge and leave you hungry for more of this type of learning and content. Each class flew by and while the work was demanding at times, it always felt fair and worthy of my time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: definitely take it! it rly helps me live a better life

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to do a lot of reading. Professor Moi is so knowledgeable in this field and really has a lot to say. However, you take a lot more out of it if you can put in the time. I also recommend meeting with the TAs before submitting papers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a highly engaging course about difficult philosophical topics. Completing the readings and engaging in discussions will allow students to learn a ton about existential philosophies.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: PLEASE TAKE IT it will change your life

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think a student should only take this class if they are truly interested in the topic, especially if they are not a philosophy major like myself. There are a lot of texts, most of them difficult to get through and at a fast pace at that. There are also essays to write, and they are great opportunities to better understand the texts and improve your own writing. This is a class that is best experienced if you have existential thoughts yourself or are interested in learning about it. I think that is what motivates one to get through books by Nietzsche, Doestoevsky, Heidegger, etc.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you have any interest in philosophy, take this course. If you don't know anything about philosophy and want to learn, this class will teach you a lot.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do the readings she says to do in class. Class is much more interesting if you have read the text.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Lots of reading but you will enjoy it

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that the content is very interesting and that you learn, what I think, is an essential way of thinking in life. Being able to stop and think about one's meaning and place in the world is probably something everyone thinks about at some point in their life, so exploring how others have thought of this question is not only helpful for one's own search, but also helps to establish a new way of thinking. I think that this class helped me immensely with this. The class is a lot of reading as you read a book a week, but all for good reason. If you can manage the amount reading and can spend time on it, it will allow you to make more out of the class and be able to make more connections and develop your own ideas. The grading is pretty vague, but seems to be mostly participation based along with three papers throughout the semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend trying the best you can to complete all of the readings no matter how difficult the subject matter is or how long the texts are. I also recommend annotating the text and taking notes, as this will help when writing essays later on as well as to get a better grip and recollection of the material.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned not only how to further analyze the writing of Nobel prize winners themselves, but also how to unpack the historical and social contexts behind them. By covering a new work of literature every week, we got a sense of the type of writing that earns this sort of recognition, in addition to an understanding of the breadth of form and topics that have been awarded the Nobel Prize.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading a book a week and analysis readings critically, it also helped with writing literary texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read cross-textually and consider themes that persisted across all texts. I learned how to place texts in their historical, political, social environments. I learned how to bring in philosophical ideologies when reading texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, analytical writing, literary criticism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critical Analysis of Literature: One of the most significant skills I developed in this course was the ability to critically analyze literary works. We learned to dissect complex texts, examining their themes, narrative structures, character development, and use of language. This involved not only understanding the surface-level content but also interpreting the deeper meanings and societal implications. 
Historical and Cultural Contextualization: The course enhanced my ability to place literary works within their historical and cultural contexts. This skill was crucial in understanding the significance of each author's work in their time and its lasting impact.
Diverse Perspectives and Empathetic Understanding: Engaging with a broad range of authors from different cultural backgrounds greatly enhanced my ability to appreciate diverse perspectives. This course encouraged an empathetic approach to literature, urging us to understand and respect viewpoints and experiences different from our own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more analytically about a literary text. I improved my skills in close reading, synthesizing my thoughts, and identifying themes that run throughout a piece.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Creative thinking and critical analysis

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Historical and cultural context in which prominent works of the 20th century were written. 
- Techniques and frames with which we can analyze literary texts 
- Practice writing interpretive essays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course provided extremely interesting insights into the literary "greats" of the 20th century and into different cultures. I learned about the roles of bystanders/authors and the many tragedies that have shaped certain countries and communities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to how to relate history with personal experiences, close reading analysis, and the more historical background on the communism and colonization.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned so much. We learned a lot about history and philosophy, and I think our explorations of so many texts in such depth made me a better critical reader and writer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our discussions of Nobel Prize-winning literature let us view these works through the lens of the author's personal background, the communal context in which they lived, and the goal with which they wrote—and of course, touched on colonialism as a recurrent theme in all the novels, short stories, dramas, poetry, and essays! I thought that although it was primarily lecture-based, I still felt that I was engaged and interested in each topic covered.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussions were very helpful to actually get to talk to about things that were sometimes too complex for me to understand on my own.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were the smartest people I've ever heard. Their lectures were incredibly insightful and I feel like I walked away from each class with new knowledge and insight and ways of looking at texts. I loved the discussion in class as well as the pre-responses to facilitate engagement.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would definitely keep the class discussion component, it was super engaging, as well as the introductions about the authors.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Pfau and Professor Stan are two of the most intelligent and well-spoken people I have ever met. Learning from them was invaluable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically think and explore different academic texts varying from more digestible personal stories to dense academic texts. I have learned a lot about trans theory, critical theory, and also feminist studies as a whole. Also being able to engage in discussion is a skill I have learned more of. Learning how to write academic papers as well as answer to larger prompts that aren't looking for a specific answer but allow you to develop your own opinion and learn how to write arguments and provide evidence for that is a great skill I have learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Knowledge of trans studies and trans "ways of thinking," improved writing skills, improved ways of thinking connecting readings together.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Understanding of what the field of trans studies is
What affects are and how that is helpful for analysis
The importance of forcing ideas and concepts from today onto experiences from the past

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class gave me a new perspective on neoliberal hyper focus on identity and the purification of those categories, like cis and trans. It also gave me a new way of thinking about the role of the state in the creation and maintenance of things like sex and race, and also how medicolegal processes formed those as inseparable identifications. It was also really interesting to learn about non normative gendered subjects in Weimar/Nazi Germany and   (post) dictatorship Argentina and how fascist persecution is not homogeneous and relies in part on economic utility to the state.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned:
1) How "trans" goes beyond just individuals that identify as transgender (and how this conceptualization of transgender as relegated to personal identity is a more recent idea, and may not be how trans actually functions in the world today)
2) How biological sex is a more complicated and political topic than a previously thought, especially (but not limited to) how it and its relation to gender are racialized
3) How to synthesize and congeal my thoughts on a complicated, often confusing topic into an essay

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The work that was done with Derrida and deconstruction helped me to develop greater critical thinking skills as it broadened my mindset and consider how the definitions and norms that we think of today can be reconstructed or questioned based on their rationale and validity. Our time on Kant and Mahmood has helped me to consider the role that ethics might truly play. Most poignantly, the idea that American ethics in doing no harm is not truly virtue. Instead, considering how I might reconsider my own decisions and everyday life in the pursuit of cultivating virtue. Finally, Althusser and Foucault have allowed me to question the origins of the various norms that I take for granted.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I build up a solid foundation for my knowledge structure about critical theories, which can be listed as social theories about freedom, liberation, power, violence, and narratology.

It also teaches you the history of contemporary intellectual shortcuts (like, what do theorists actually mean when they say ‘gender’, ‘settler colonialism’, ‘patriarchy’ vs what the popular belief is)

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

After finishing the course, you will come away with a different way of examining the ways that we go about daily life which is applicable to anyone considering policy or other spheres of study as well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

The demand of the class also is minimal and doesn't feel like a lot since its not like you are being tested the next class on what you read; the class promotes you understanding and reading at your own pace the texts to be able to understand what is being said in class. Take this course esepcially if you want to read more and read these types of texts and engage with them in a relaxed and growth-centered manner but dont have the time in your personal life or other classes to do so.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. A better understanding of cinema as an entity through time since its conception
2. A stronger sense of what matters to filmmakers at various points in time and how that manifests in their work
3. How to analyze the less obvious elements of film in pursuit of the author's purpose

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read film theory papers and understand them in regard to their historical background. I also learned how film theorist engage with one another over the years and changed ideologies with the advent of new technologies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about major film theorists and their theories, including bell hooks, Bazin, Siegfried Kracauer and Erwin Panofsky. I learned how to write a paper about theory and I learned how to write and analyze films through various theoretical lenses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Overall, I gained a new understanding for how film theory has emerged and changed over time. Before, I knew film theory only from bits and pieces that I had read (out of context) in other courses, but this course really helped to frame and contextualize theory as a whole. I most enjoyed the semiotics unit and how investigating cinema as a language influenced more modern theorists in thinking about the socio-political impacts of film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned some historical background on cinema and early film, as well as more applied techniques like understanding film production/construction of shots/the effect they have and how to critically evaluate the position a film might have relative to its social/political context.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: From classical film theory to modern and contemporary film theory. Learned how to read theories and analyze films with the theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the history and ideologies surrounding specific figures who have contributed to the development of film theory. I feel that my understanding of realism and identity as it relates to cinema strengthened after contextualizing films with in-class lectures. Finally, I had the opportunity to expand upon and adapt a paper to fit new criteria. I appreciated the space to rework and build a paper after the feedback stage as I often abandon papers once they are submitted.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Film analysis, how to understand theoretical readings, and how to apply those readings to films.

Often times the class stayed silent or surface-level when asked questions related to the readings or films. I feel that either making the class entirely lecture-based or cultivating an environment that inspires participation would enhance intellectual simulation. Because the readings were dense, I feel that assigning smaller sections would increase students engagement and understanding with them.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

The course equipped me with critical frameworks to analyze how different media forms - from print to digital platforms - shape human experience and social relationships. Key theoretical concepts like technological determinism, cultural techniques, and media archaeology enhanced my ability to examine the complex interplay between media, technology, and society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

In this class, I learned a lot about the concept of media and the historical process of media. In particular, I am deeply impressed by McLuhan's theory. He taught me that media can influence our perception and shape our society. And I also realized commodification and entertainment, it makes me know that we need to keep our own judgment in the market to find the real value

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that bad behavior is really not a binary at all, it is moreso just something that doesn't fit with the dominant ideologies of the time. I also learned more about the works of important figures of sociological thought like Goffman, Becker, Foucault, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned a general overview of what is categorized as bad behavior in society. This was approached through a predominantly sociology driven lens, given we focused on often how what we see as bad is constructed through social norms over time. Likewise, we looked at certain historical examples of how the categorization of bad behavior as evolved, while also taking a moment to assess the true essence of morality through the lens of philosophy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class fundamentally altered the way I perceive everything around me. Prof. Bassiri does an amazing job at taking the material we learn during the lectures and applying it to relatable concepts within modernity, allowing us to seamlessly transfer the knowledge we gain inside of this class to the outside world. One of my favorite things I learned was Foucault's theory of counter-conduct, which necessitates questioning external authority in a manner not conducive to external pathologization. Specifically, I was able to apply this concept broadly to my life, because I became aware that every time I purchase makeup, I'm feeding into the prevailing norm of beauty standards. From developing this perceptual awareness, I could subsequently begin altering my behavior, opposing corporation's capitalistic tendencies to monetize consumer's insecurities, changing the way I acquire makeup to fundamentally undermine the validity of the system itself.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the post-war discussion and knowledge surrounding the Holocaust and WWII in Germany. It was something that I had never learned about; I always learned about the Holocaust, but never the intellectual aftermath. I also learned some film methods and techniques, since this class was an ALP and we watched a decent amount of movies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed a range of knowledge, skills, and insights that have significantly enriched my understanding of the subject matter. One specific thing I learned was the importance of critical thinking and analysis. Through various assignments and class discussions, I honed my ability to evaluate arguments, assess evidence, and identify logical fallacies, enabling me to approach complex issues with a more discerning eye. Additionally, I gained a deeper appreciation for the power of effective communication. Whether it was through written assignments and class discussions, I learned how to articulate my ideas clearly and persuasively, tailoring my message to different audiences and contexts. Lastly, this course exposed me to diverse perspectives and challenged my preconceived notions. By engaging with classmates from various backgrounds and exploring different viewpoints, I developed a greater sense of empathy and cultural awareness, fostering a more inclusive and open-minded way of thinking. Overall, these three specific learnings—critical thinking, effective communication, and embracing diversity—have not only enhanced my academic abilities but also equipped me with invaluable skills for navigating the complexities of the world beyond the classroom.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: All about WWII and post germany

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the depths of how Germany and German people responded to the Holocaust and, as the course is titled, came to terms with their past. I was able to develop a greater perspective on the Holocaust and a better understanding of everything that went into the persecution of Jews and others during the Holocaust.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: reading academic/historical texts, approaching difficult topics with nuance

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about the Holocaust and German reconciliation with its past, ways to consider multiple perspectives on historical events, how German understanding of the Holocaust changed in the decades after the Holocaust.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I liked learning 1) how to analyze movies/relate them to the historical context 2) more theoretical understandings of guilt, morality, etc. 3) Critical eye towards memorial culture

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about controversial issues of the past. I also learned how to put myself in unique perspectives that I have not experienced. I had never really used films to this extent in a class before so it was great to utilize them as a film enthusiast.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was one of my first times engaging with historical content on a more meta level. As such, I learned a lot about how to compare, contrast and critique secondary sources with a bigger focus on how the authors interpreted events rather than the actual events themselves. I also gained lots of knowledge in the specific domain of the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critically analyze texts and try to hone down on the key messages of the author. Use both fiction and non-fiction sources to come to insightful conclusions. Structure writing in a straightforward and digestible way, while still being able to be creative and thoughtful in writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, close reading, and most importantly a lot of knowledge on what Germany looked like after the Holocaust which (at least in my education experience) had been overlooked.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about memory culture and how a country and a people move past horrific history. Specifically, I learned about how Germany reemerged after the Holocaust, different theories regarding German responsibility, and bringing justice to Nazi perpetrators, all within the context of academic articles and popular media such as movies and TV.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: analysis of german film, german guilt and coming to terms with the holocaust, analysis of holocaust memorials

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about a side of the Holocaust that I have never discovered. The post-war side, focussing on Germany confronting its actions and past. I have also improved my reading analysis and writing skills while also understanding ways the in-depth interpretation that can be found in sources we have read.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: history of russian literature, aspects of russian identity as it pertains to the great patriotic war, and the social and political context of the soviet union

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: creative writing, analyzing literary pieces

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned about the internal structure and meaning of individual stories while tracing the historical development of Russian prose within shifting political and cultural contexts. I explored how identity is shaped, contested, and expressed in these artistic works. Complementing the readings, I engaged with acclaimed Russian films, comparing how key themes and identities are portrayed differently in cinematic versus written narratives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The most importqnt theme of the course was HOW Russians coped with dramatic change. Many of the texts delved into personal histories of tough times throughout Russian history specifically during and after the fall fo the soviet union.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways to analyze 1900s-2000s Russian media in translation, how to access many of these sources, and general themes of this media!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better ability to analyze literature and film, and I am able to do so within specific cultural context. I have also improved my reading and presentation skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three things that I learned in this course are how to analyze and explore texts, greater understand the context of the texts/films and how that plays a role, and explore major themes and symbolism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Contextualizing works of literature by examining how they connect to their literary period (and to the periods preceding/after), discovering the purpose of characters and plot points.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Generally, I learned more about Russian history and the influence historical events had on the development of literature from the Twentieth Century up until now. This includes how at the beginning of the Twentieth Century, there was an air of anticipation for the revolution, but also generally for change with the government as well as social and material circumstances. I learned how within literature there was a period of experimentation where art forms were being mixed together and explored different themes such as gay and lesbian relationships, as well as the position of women in society. I also learned about the labor camps people were sent to that were in places with extreme weather, or where everyone would most certainly die either from the conditions or at the hands of the guards.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned more about contemporary Russian film and literature, especially those that have become prominent in the last few years.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The conflict between ideological loyalty and material harm prevention—whether in the regulation of AI-generated disinformation or in the defense of capitalist market structures—reveal the same pattern repeats: ideology-first positions prioritize abstract principles even when faced with clear evidence of harm, while material-first positions seek to address concrete damage, even at the cost of ideological purity. This essay will show how this underlying dynamic shapes both debates over AI regulation and the longstanding capitalism versus communism controversy.In the current debates surrounding AI regulation, especially around deepfake imagery and disinformation, the divide is sharp. Anti-regulation advocates adopt an ideology-first stance, prioritizing principles of free speech absolutism and market autonomy. Organizations like the Cato Institute frame any attempt to regulate AI content as a slippery slope to censorship or dangerous government overreach. Similarly, the narrative that "innovation must be free from interference" dismisses the material harms caused by AI disinformation — such as manipulated election outcomes, voter suppression, and the erosion of public trust. The underlying ideological commitment to liberty and free market operation remains firm even in the face of mounting evidence that AI technologies, left unchecked, can profoundly destabilize democratic institutions.Conversely, pro-regulation advocates adopt a material-first position, focusing not on preserving ideological purity, but on minimizing measurable harm. They prioritize policies like mandatory watermarking of AI-generated media, platform accountability for disinformation campaigns, and transparency requirements for algorithmic content distribution. Their arguments are grounded in concrete evidence: AI models have exacerbated biases in hiring, deepened misinformation flows, and enabled new forms of exploitation and surveillance. Rather than focusing on deontological arguments about abstract rights, material-first proponents insist that preventing real-world damage must take precedence, even if it entails some limitations on absolute free expression or market freedom.This structure mirrors the capitalism versus communism debate throughout the twentieth century. Capitalist apologetics frequently operated from an ideology-first perspective, framing free markets and competition as "natural" forces immune to political critique. Ideologies of meritocracy — that wealth and success reflect personal virtue — mystified systemic inequalities, obscuring the exploitation and structural violence embedded in global capitalism. Even as ecological collapse, labor precarity, and extreme wealth gaps became more visible, defenders of market ideology dismissed these harms as "externalities" rather than evidence of fundamental flaws. Their loyalty remained not to empirical outcomes but to the abstract sanctity of market competition.On the other side, critiques of capitalism — including socialist and communist thought — adopt a material-first approach. These critiques prioritize harm reduction: alleviating poverty, protecting ecological systems, ensuring workers' rights, and reducing systemic inequality. They are less concerned with preserving the ideological purity of economic "freedom" and more concerned with minimizing the tangible suffering produced by capitalist systems. Whether through labor protections, wealth redistribution, or environmental regulation, material-first critiques demand that abstract ideals yield when faced with material devastation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In the traditional model of ideological control, elites dominate mental production by distributing first-order ideological content: direct messages about what is true, good, or desirable. However, this is no longer the only — or even the primary — mechanism. In the contemporary world, not only does mental production distribute first-order ideology, but also the enforcement of second-order ideology additionally distributes first-order ideology. Seemingly neutral frameworks like "free speech," "anti-misinformation," and "anti-hate speech" are second-order ideologies that not only prescribe how the media should distribute first-order content but universalize first-order values through their enforcement. Thus, the public inherits first-order ideologies not only from the media itself but derive them from universal prescriptions of what kinds of communication are deemed legitimate.Consider "misinformation" enforcement. During the Cold War, elites not only flooded the media with anti-communist messages; they also framed sympathy toward communism itself as "misinformation" or "subversion." Thus, communism being bad was not only simply conveyed through the arguments the media made, but through ruling the discussion of alternatives as inherently illegitimate and a form of misinformation. In this context, "misinformation" as a second-order ideology was a direct extension of a first-order ideological battle: capitalism versus communism.In today's technocratic context, however, "misinformation" serves a different second-order function. The contemporary enforcement of "misinformation" on the surface seems to be a simple second-order filter for accuracy. However, such a filter spreads a universalist belief in objective truth — the idea that there exists a singular, recognizable reality that must be protected and disseminated for the sake of social cohesion and progress. Through this enforcement, public life becomes organized around a metaphysics of universal objectivity, where being properly informed is valued above all else.The antithesis of this is free speech absolutism. Media and education have long glorified individual liberty, often portraying censorship as synonymous with tyranny. The enforcement of free speech absolutism — treating any regulation of speech as dangerous — quietly installs this ideological lesson as a universal framework: that freedom is valued above all else, even at the expense of others' feelings, social cohesion, or truth itself. In this framework, we value our freedom over information integrity, emotional safety, and democratic stability, perpetuating the first-order libertarian ideal without openly stating it.Similarly, anti-hate speech policies reveal how second-order frameworks distribute first-order ideology. Modern pluralistic societies emphasize the protection of marginalized groups, and content celebrating diversity and inclusion is everywhere. The enforcement of "anti-hate" regulations carries this deep implication: that emotional harm and subjective feelings deserve institutional protection. Thus, anti-hate enforcement teaches that our feelings should be valued — that emotional safety is not merely a private concern, but a political and communicative standard that reshapes the public sphere.In each case, second-order enforcement distributes first-order ideology by naturalizing its assumptions about legitimacy, safety, harm, and truth. What appears as neutral procedural management — combating misinformation, protecting speech, ensuring emotional safety — is in fact the continuation of elite interests by other means. Thus, mental production is no longer simply about distributing beliefs; it is about embedding frameworks that structure the conditions of belief themselves. Today's ideological domination operates not only on the level of what we think, but even more profoundly on what kind of relationship to truth, harm, and freedom we are allowed to have.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
