question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We covered, in somewhat equal parts, Marx's (and Engel's) original thoughts and writings and their modern counterparts in Marxism and Marxist [ecology, feminism, etc.]. Marx's theories of the world were already useful in understanding our modern world, but we also learned about what was different between now/then, and some places where Marx failed to see the entire picture. To be specific: we learned about Marx's earlier ideas of humanism (alienation/estrangement, species-being, reification/fetishism) and how some Marxists viewed them (namely, Jameson's view on popular culture), about Marx's later ideas of historical materialism and his analyses of history (including Capital and the value it represents, primitive accumulation, class struggle, etc.) and how some Marxists view them (for example, Malm's Marxist Ecology and Fraser's take on Marxist Feminism), and ultimately how these two Marx-es (among some others) could serve as a window to a 'larger Marx' - representing the entirety of Marx and his philosophy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

- Concept of structure and super structure was my favorite

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed listening to Professor Lubiano's lectures—she is one of the most intelligent and well-spoken professors I've ever met—and has a profound ability to integrate the theory and literature we encounter in class. I also appreciated how she elevated "colloquial" knowledge to the level of the academy (asking us, for example, to include hypertext and internet sources within our final paper, or bringing up the example of the online forum on dragons). This is something I haven't seen any other professor do before, and as someone who has a few reservations about the nature of literature and the academy, something I didn't take for granted. Additionally, I enjoyed the format of having one or two students come up with discussion questions for each work we talked about in class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was an extremely tedious course, but the work was minimal (3 short essays and one longer final paper). Professor Lubiano is very intelligent but often struggles with conveying information, so her lectures are quite disjointed and convoluted. Many times, she would leave no room for students to speak during the entire 2.5-hour class. There was a lot of assigned reading, but, as stated, we rarely discussed them and were instead lectured at about them for 2.5 hours. And, as the lectures were so hard to follow anyway, it felt like doing the readings was pointless. If you’re looking to learn something about literature, look elsewhere. There are many other excellent professors in the English department with significantly more engaging methods of instruction.

I also learned how to analyze art and uncover nuance within visual language.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is really not much work, but be prepared for really vague assignments, especially for the papers. The only real "guidelines" for the papers were in the syllabus, and that was just to tell you how long the paper should be. Papers are "open to interpretation", but it can be hard to know what exactly he wants. It would also help to just speak to him directly, as he is really a very kind professor. The big papers can just be a little daunting when you're not sure what to write about. Other than that though, great course, I would reccomend.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it.  If you're interested not only in art, but also in Spanish history, the political and social unrest and censorship of the Franco and post-Franco periods, the feminist movements, and how all of this history has been manifested in art and visual language.  José-María is amazing, so kind and supportive and such an inspirational and intelligent educator.  He is truly passionate about the subjects of his course, and he truly cares about his students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor and TA really helped us by guiding our readings with complementary texts that we used as tools to better understand the books. I liked that we always discussed these texts in class, and everyone could add their own ideas, which made the discussions richer and helped with critical thinking, especially with literature. Their guidance was very important because the books we studied were new and there weren’t many resources online. Also, the open discussions encouraged everyone to speak, which helped us see different perspectives. As the representative delegate, I could also see that our guidance was much stronger compared to other universities, where students sometimes showed a more superficial understanding, probably because the material wasn't always structured (in a class) and taught by a professor, like it is at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell a student to take this class if they have a genuine interest in literature and truly enjoy reading. It’s a very complete class because you learn literary concepts that improve your critical thinking, and you also get exposed to important cultural and social phenomena happening in France. I would also say that you need to feel confident with your french skills, because the class requires a good level of understanding and speaking. At the same time, it’s a great way to improve your speaking, because you have to express complex ideas in a very supportive learning environment. But most importantly, genuine interest is key. Since the class isn’t required, having real motivation will make the experience very enjoyable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- i learned a new way of writing - writing as a process of thinking and discovery rather than argumentation - which really helped me deepen my understanding of the philosophy i learn in class
- The attention journals helped me ground my learning in everyday life and always apply things i learn with the help of attention
- This course really sparked my interest in literature and philosophy and allowed me to decide that i want to major in GCS

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about looking at literature through philosophy.
I came in with no prior knowledge of Weil, Beauvoir, and Murdoch, but I feel I have a very strong grasp on them and their philosophies now.
I also developed skills in creating a concise presentation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Just as Simone Weil wrote in her essays, in the right use of schoolwork, attention is extensively practiced. So I guess the most important three things I learned are attention to others and other things, Weil, Beauvoir, and Murdoch’s visions of existence, and of course essay writing methods.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Became intimately familiar with philosophies of Simone Weil, Simone de Beauvoir, and Iris Murdoch through close readings. Learned ethics in a way that was immediately applicable to everyday life. Gained insights about the influence of these thinkers on one another, particularly Simone Weil of whom I had close to no knowledge of before entering the course. One of my favorite things was when Professor Moi filled in historical/philosophical context around these thinkers (wartime, surrounding literature, Wittgenstein, Hegel, etc)--made it feel less like narrowing in on these random philosophers in a vacuum.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned about the philosophies and moral frameworks of Weil, Murdoch, and Beauvoir
2) I recognized ways in which these philosophical theories resonated with me and have a fresh perspective on my own behavior and way of living. 
3) I have become more conscious of the ways in which I do and don't pay attention in my life, and have begun cultivating that skill in my own behavior.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- i loved the seminar structured way of teaching that was interspersed with explanations of other philosophers (ie i liked professor moi's connections of weil, beauvoir, and murdoch with wittgenstein, cavell, and plato) because they not only allowed me to think deeper about the concepts i learn, but also open up new territories for me to explore in the future
- the weekly attention journals are also very helpful, because it forces me to sit down and reflect on the philosophy and also put things i learn into practice (paying attention)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Moi encouraged genuine reflection with our attention journals. These were not graded on the A-F scale, which allowed them to be purely for our own building of the skill of attention without having to pander or have a grade in the back of our minds. I would definitely keep this part of the course. I also found Professor Moi's lectures interesting. The breaking up of the three philosophers into three separate parts rather than going between them also made them digestible so that they didn't get convoluted.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Absolutely, when the material gets a bit too hard, Professor Moi made slides to accommodate and overall the in-class discussions were very fruitful. And I really liked the idea of using Slack channel to talk about difficult concepts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Smaller readings allowed me to pay closer attention to each text and get more out of subsequent lectures and discussions. I liked the attention journals as a way to keep me closely engaged with the texts throughout the week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought that in terms of content, the course flowed quite nicely. I thought beginning with Weil and ending with Murdoch (from our big three names) was the ideal order, with Weil's concept of attention framing the whole course and Murdoch's vision-based moral theory bringing together attention and action, as well as offering a more realistic and individualized moral approach (compared to Weil's saintly expectations and Beauvoir's more politically-grounded perspective).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class if you are interesting in philosophy, literature, theory or anything related at all. Note that this is not a feminist philosophy class, more so a class about women philosophers. I think these are philosophers that are underrated in the academic canon, although Beauvoir is quite popular now. But definitely Simone Weil is an underrated writer and philosopher that everyone should read. Professor Moi is also a great teacher who understands students and the texts quite well. The amount of texts you read in this class is perfect. Long enough that you get a deep enough understanding of the philosopher, but also not too long so that it becomes unmanageable. The texts are also enlightening and perfectly difficult to understand so when you do get some insight it feels nice and illuminating.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The current discussion and relevance of Ecomedia. It helped me expand my conception of media and its relationship with the environment and ecological issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better theoretical understanding of eco-media as a scholarly field, I had access to a summary of discussions concerning Ecology in the Humanities (such as the Anthropocene and derived concepts), I had access to case studies of art and media related to Ecological discussions, especially in China.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Very interesting articles, learned a lot from these readings. For example, "bare life", "power relationship".
The professor offers many profound films that discuss ecological issues in society. Analyze and discuss these movies in conjunction with reading.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I first learned what eco-media is, and what topics and methods eco-media covers. Secondly, I learned how to analyze scenes in a film that a director might be inclined to express. Third, I learned a conceptual framework from academic film reviews that can provide a deeper perspective for interpreting films related to environmental issues, such as global waste, mining industries, toxicity, manufactured landscape, and multispecies entanglement.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how different groups of people embrace eco-media as an approach to environmental criticism. Most importantly, I learned how varied directors portrayed manifestations of environmental degradation differently to approach the questions concerning agency and subalternity. 
2. I learned methods of analyzing not only eco-media works but also its materiality. Specifically, I learned about how they are produced, circulated and consumed. More importantly, I learned how the production and circulation of media could impose secondary toxic effects on the environment.
3. The course content also helps me to learn to situate and historicize different forms of precarity regarding one's embeddedness within global capitalism.

response_text:
The dialectic is never a move back but always forward and through -- that's something very important to keep in mind for my dissertation project.
Philosophy will always be very hard for me. I do feel a little better equipped to understand what the Frankfurt school is/does, but I'm still very much intimidated by its massive scope.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- This course over-delivered in terms of intellectual history; aside from familiarity with first-generation Frankfurt School thinkers, I now feel more comfortable embarking on studies of earlier German philosophy mainstays--namely Kant and Hegel. 
- The asking for questions and then incorporating answers into lecture was a pedagogical masterclass. Generally, the pedagogical decisions seemed well-reasoned in what seemed like a difficult classroom (various backgrounds and interests).
- I feel like my analytic rigor in reading philosophic text has been strengthened, in a strictly logical sense, a historicist sense, and on the level of the form of the argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A close knowledge of one of the formative thinkers in queer theory, which generated further insights into various developments in the field; for instance, the move from "anti-homophobic" to "queer," the relationship between feminist theory and queer theory, and the affective turn. Close attention to the deployment of the personal and the meaning and troubles of identification and cross-identification.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Archival Research. The most important reason that I enroll in this course.
2. Learning to Sit with Ambiguity. This course taught me that not every question has a clear answer—and that’s okay. Through Sedgwick’s writing and our discussions, I became more comfortable with complexity, contradiction, and not knowing.
3. Collaborative Thinking. The seminar environment encouraged a slower, more relational way of thinking.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read in both paranoid and reparative modes. I became very familiar with the concept of the personal archive. This class expanded my idea of what analysis can look like, and I appreciated the extent of the freedom we were given in our identifications with Sedgwick and the playfulness involved in the critiques in that (non)relationship.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have a much better sense of the trajectory of Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick's career, the formation of Queer Theory as a field, and the main contributions Sedgwick made (triangulation, minoritizing/universalizing, the closet, the affective turn, illness, Proust). I also learned a lot about archival work and processes of memorialization.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The Archive Diary and Exhibit Review were especially effective in deepening my engagement with the course. The Archive Diary encouraged hands-on, reflective research that made Sedgwick’s work feel personal and alive, while the Exhibit Review allowed me to think critically about curation, memory, and affect.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the seminar style of the class and I felt that we had a good report, facilitated in large part (or perhaps created) by Professor Wiegman. I always look forward to this class because of our weekly debates and how we get lost into Sedgwick's dense writing. I also really enjoyed going into the archive with members of the class as it transformed what was ordinarily an individual experience into a group one. I liked the individual aspect of curating our own archives of Sedgwick's work and archives.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: Formally bringing in in non-Sedgwick texts that we ended up being in conversation with anyway, such as Marlon Ross.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Engaging with Sedgwick’s personal archive while reading her published work created a dynamic interplay between theory and material life. It made the abstract feel embodied.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Eve Sedgwick's writing was stimulating in and of itself. I appreciated how engaged my peers were in the conversation every week. Professor Wiegman always had incredible insights and contextualized the moment that Sedgwick was writing in and the debates around various feminist interests. I felt very lucky to have a professor and a group of like-minded peers who added so much to my reading and understanding of Sedgwick's work.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Being able to talk across Sedgwick's published work, the archive, the events she was invited to and involved with, the movements she participated in, etc. enriched the conversations. Often in courses that do literary theory, the 'author dead' (whether or not they are actually dead) so we aren't invested in conversations around what they were reading or who they were talking to at a given moment. But since we were all deep in Sedgwick's papers, it was 'stimulating' (Sedgwick would appreciate that that is the word being used in this question) to be able to bring up in class 'oh that thought is one that came up in X email to Y person and was actually related there to this other idea that isn't in the published work explicitly, Z).

2. i've learned to ask what instrumental value a diagnostic category has and reverse engineering the image of mental illness to deduce the picture of normality at that specific time — and ask why were these norms the norms being valued

4. how to have conversations across disciplines

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This course was very enriching and allowed me to develop several important skills and insights: 
1) Exploration of Austrian Postwar Literature and Film: I gained a deep understanding of four major Austrian writers and filmmakers—Thomas Bernhard, Elfriede Jelinek, Michael Haneke, and Ulrich Seidl—whose works are foundational to postwar cultural and literary criticism in Austria.
2) Close Reading and Film Analysis: I improved my ability to engage in close reading and film analysis, emphasizing how to critically unpack texts and visual narratives in relation to broader social and cultural contexts.
3) Understanding Representations of Violence: I explored how graphic depictions of violence can serve as tools for education and enlightenment, pushing myself to remain open-minded about the purpose and impact of such representations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained exposure to a variety of Austrian films that I might not have encountered otherwise, broadening my understanding of Austrian film culture and its unique themes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was highly interested in breaking down the notion of a Eurocentric Humanistic ideal due to the nature of the course design, i.e. transgressive thinkers. However, I learnt that often in academia, one has to bite the bullet and decide what battles to fight. As such I learnt to disengage from arguments that did not give me back fruitful ideas and were unproductive to thinking critically about the issues the artists' work that was the primary material in the course was trying to do. The actual work was often buried in the discussions about the artists themselves and the participants were not asked to refrain from make universal statements about the literary or film-studies based values expressed in the works. I learnt that when the discussion becomes performative, I must quietly save my labor for when I have the intellectual and emotional energy. I enjoyed quite a few of the readings, both primary and secondary, but found that the discussions were often overshadowed by manspreading in the workplace, an issue often unaddressed in the graduate seminar, a workspace often disguised as solely a classroom. Lastly, and on a positive note, I learnt how to identify textual evidence to dialectically decipher the place a given text occupies in the literary history as visible from the contemporary moment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learnt how to theorize my interpretation of a text based on a close reading instead of using theoretical lenses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close readings, discourse on humanism in pre-war Austria, and film/image analysis

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I definitely got better at close readings!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was particularly beneficial in providing opportunities to practice close reading via discussion posts. The course helped me develop a stronger understanding of literary studies as a discipline, including its language. It finally aided in developing my understanding and deployment of form to buttress close readings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The overall learning environment was positive, and the course structure effectively supported my learning:* Student-Led Discussions: I appreciated the collaborative approach, as students leading parts of the discussion fostered engagement and new perspectives.
* Weekly Discussion Posts: Writing weekly posts allowed me to engage deeply with the materials, and I appreciated that the instructor thoughtfully read and provided feedback on all posts.
* Instructor Engagement: The instructor created an encouraging atmosphere for intellectual exploration.However, I think the discussions could benefit from integrating the weekly posts more directly into the class conversations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment, I appreciated the instructor's openness and flexibility, which created a welcoming space for discussion. The weekly Canvas responses were particularly effective in fostering engagement and reflection, and I think this component should be kept for future classes. However, I would suggest incorporating more structured guidance from the instructor, as well as adding theoretical background and close readings to provide a stronger foundation for analyzing the films. These additions would enhance the learning experience by balancing discussion with deeper context and analysis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professsor-instructor was highly amenable to being flexible about the primary textual materials under study in this class, especially with regard to the sensitivity of some participants and an incident that left many shook beyond performative solidarity with a participant new to the program. Moreover, the professor-instructor was kind about my own medical condition related to psychiatric health and did not hold it against me when I had to retreat from energetic participation into passive note-taking mode. I did not feel pressure to partake in any opinion-based consensus creation when the loudest members of the seminar were doing their usual think-out-loud discussions. I think the best part of this course was the discussion posts where the value-systems of each participants may be seen through close analysis of their writing styles and philosophical standpoints.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course was intellectually engaging, but there is room for improvement in the selection of secondary readings: Some texts were excellent (I particularly enjoyed the Rita Felski reading), but others were less effective due to unclear writing or arguments (e.g., Ahmed, Berlant, Nelson). The syllabus could have included foundational texts like Susan Sontag’s "On Photography" and "Looking at War," which were mentioned in class but not assigned. These could have enriched our discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made this class stimulating was the exposure to a range of Austrian films that I wouldn’t have encountered otherwise. However, it could have been more intellectually stimulating with a stronger theoretical foundation and more guided analysis. Incorporating close readings of the texts, deeper engagement with key concepts, and connecting these ideas more explicitly to the films would have enhanced the intellectual depth. Additionally, balancing open discussions with structured input from the instructor could make the class more engaging and thought-provoking. One area for improvement would be including more trigger warnings and regularly checking in on students' mental health, as the nature of the films often addressed challenging and sensitive topics.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: If the women were encouraged to speak more by asking the men to pipe down sometimes. I would have loved to see more decolonial thought on humanism as an exclusionary method to control humans and their poetic abilities as a member of the planet on a continuum with other forms of life and the material world that sustains them, rather than the notion of humans as elevated beings in control over the material reality upon which they are parasitic. far from being nihilistic, this poetic idea of a human as creative and trangressive rather than ascriptive and normative could have been the impetus for more stimulating and self-degrandizing set of discussions rather than 'redemption' as the limit of thought in the secularized versions of a Euro-Christian humanism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Professor Nash surveyed the many, often conflicting, ways that (Black) feminisms have understood sexuality, gender, the university, law, identity, form, and beauty. Genealogies of feminisms—Professor Nash asks us to attend to the plurality of theoretical feminist frameworks—too often narrate its development through the contributions of white women, eliding the work of Black, third world, and indigenous feminists. Professor Nash corrects this omission.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

2. The legal basis and majors legal scholars that underpin a lot of historical and contemporary feminist theory
3. Knowledge of different movements within feminist theory, e.g Standpoint Theory, Transnational Feminism, etc

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked professor Nash's way of structuring class conversations, beginning with an overview and context then brainstorming key terms before opening up the discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Nash is an exemplary pedagogue. She began each seminar by inviting us to each pose a question about the materials at hand, then deftly facilitated our conversation around these inquiries. She insisted we pay attention to the nitty gritty: to the context of the theorizations, to their forms of articulation, and to the unspoken intellectual currents. She challenged us to stay with what we found most challenging rather than deflect or arrive to some facile consensus.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the way Jen opened class, by giving a summary of our previous week’s readings/discussions and connecting with our current readings, as well as her flagging some important themes, connections, and terms we might want to sit with during class. And I liked how we oriented class around questions that we prepared before class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take the class!!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is such an important course, not only academically, but for life's outlook and for acquiring ways of knowing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This course was excellent. I appreciate the attention to specificity and the care taken when editing writing in groups. I learned the following:
o Note taking is vital - It is more important to capture how I feel about material rather than block quotes and theoretical applicability. This include WHERE the source material comes from.
o Trust my own voice. I don't have to adhere to academic writing standard if they do not satisfy my interpretation
o Solicit peer feedback. Often times, if peers can understand what I am writing, then the writing is clear. I cannot assume people understand what I am writing about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Took my note-taking more seriously and learned about different techniques 
2. I feel like I was able to get more clear and precise in my writing - working on slowing down and letting a sentence to one thing at a time 
3. Dissecting others' individual sentences and figuring out what's wrong with them - being able to pinpoint this more precisely

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I learned how to find my own voice in my writing and work on editing my and others' work for clarity and cohesion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to more critically and self-reflectively read my own writing and assess my own writing practices. I have a better understanding of how to manage long-term writing projects like dissertations. I am familiar with the teachings of the most popular academic style guides and have practiced implementing their suggestions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to identity what was going wrong in my writing and how to fix it.
I learned what a plethora of academic authors have to say on the topic of writing through class book reviews.
I learned how to note-take effectively and consistently, and why that matters.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) Writing good sentences because my sentences were horribly confusing and prevented my thoughts from being effectively communicated. 2) Writing groups can be very helpful to the overall writing process, both mentally/emotionally through discussion about the process and making progress in writing. 3) Writing class is absolutely needed for graduate students, especially those who are interested in PhD work. In a field of work where writing essentially is the job, it is almost fraudulent that graduate programs do not teach the basic skills. There ought to be creative ways that graduate programs teach students write throughout the curriculum, rather than simply claiming that writing skills should be learned before students enter graduate school. The education system today simply does not work that way anymore.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Perhaps the most important skill I gained from this class was an ability to really critically contemplate the details of my writing experience, in a manner that often seems "irrelevant" to graduate students. We come to think we know how to write and therefore do not pay attention to the minutiae of what we're doing and forget that each little thing is a choice--one that matters significantly. I also gained confidence in (and excitement about) the practice of sharing my work with others productively and began developing a note-taking habit unique to my PhD work that I know will serve me well as I head into my reading year and teh dissertation stage of the program.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned invaluable skills about how to organize my research, take notes with lasting meaning, and write with improved clarity. This class was the first one devoted to writing instruction that I had taken in years, and it was a wonderful addition to a grad school curriculum. People so often assume that graduate students know how to write, but it is very helpful to have a course specifically geared toward improving graduate-level writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to take generative notes. 
2. How do I pace myself in writing towards long projects?
3. I learned how to share my work and receive feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Well, I may not raise myself to the level of three here, but in general I found this course refreshing in a semester where I was mired in irritatingly dense theoretical prose that made me want to rip all my hair out and eat it. I do think it taught me to pay a little more attention to brevity in my sentences -- to break them up and make them shorter when I can. For that alone it's been of use. I also think it taught me a lot about how totally irritating and inward-facing academia is, and how difficult it is to really produce anything of worth in this environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the conversational method of instruction, Professor Moi's class is master class on writing. Here examples are clear, approachable and appropriate. I especially appreciate the amount of content she makes available on Sakai. One of the take aways for me is to be more deliberate about my writing practice, and allow myself to free write without judgement. I also appreciate seeing my peers writing, it validates my writing ability and show me what I am capable of given patience, focus, and time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Created an environment where critique between students and their respective writings didn't feel personal.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the targeted and weekly individual feedback from the Professor was invaluable. She clearly spent so much of her time helping us improve, and I (and we) am / are better for it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Moi gave generous and extensive feedback on our writing every week. I felt really privileged to have that kind of attention on my writing. I also benefitted from regularly hearing a wide range of perspectives from other students in mini-workshop settings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated how multi-dimensional the learning was. I learned via oral discussion, as well as via written examples ("some sentences" exercise). I appreciated getting to read about writing (book reviews), write about writing (notetaking essay), write (200 words weekly), and edit myself & others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The collaborative environment allowed me to see where other students are in their writing. I always felt that I was an inadequate writer because in graduate programs, I read published essays that have been refined (thus high quality) and my own writing, which I often submit quickly (thus low quality). But seeing other people write made me realize that writing is difficult for everyone. And working through writing together helped me to be ok with my own writing and see how my writing could improve through writings of others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I'm not sure how it was done or who was responsible, but from the first day of this course the learning environment was incredibly comfortable, caring, and productive. A course like this requires so much vulnerability, difficult for anyone but especially for those early on in a career in which our ability to do THIS ONE THING very well feels crucial. It was so wonderful to find myself in a space in which that vulnerability, while maybe still a bit uncomfortable, was not frightening--in which I could laugh at myself--in which I felt unconcerned about sharing honest and sometimes challenging feedback with others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked have regular writing exercises that encouraged us to try different techniques and styles.  The readings were generally very helpful. I also liked seeing examples from my classmates, particularly about how they take notes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The weekly "some sentences" practice taught me how to edit my work and that of others. Also, knowing that Toril would be giving me feedback on my 200 words, I became more precise in my writing to get more input on content and less on structure. 
The note-taking practice allowed me to get to know my mind and begin figuring out how I am as a writer and thinker.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Toril's frank attitude and her open approach to discussion is probably the most important aspect of the course, even if it is sometimes the most terrifying aspect as well!I would probably keep Some Sentences, albeit with the caveat that sometimes you have absolutely NO DESIRE to stand by anything you wrote in your 200 words some weeks. (There should be a big button you get to push that bails you out of your chair in the seminar room if that's the case, like in a fighter plane that's going down.)I also liked writing the book reviews a lot and wish there were more longer assignments in the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The stakes are always high when your writing can be displayed for scrutiny, I appreciate this rigor and grew from it. This aspect of the course kept us on our toes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Precision and level of specificity and attention to detail to sentences. Writing the 200-word papers and getting feedback very quickly afterward.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course was very stimulating, but I did feel that some of the style guides got repetitive after a while and those readings (+ the notes I took on them) took up time that I could have spent practicing writing.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: "Some sentences" was by far the most stimulating part. It helped me move beyond recognizing "bad" writing, to knowing what exactly about it was "bad" and how to fix it.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Fixing sentences together as a class was really important. And also, realized that the letters/sentences on paper are the objective mirror of my internal thinking. So I had to fix the sentences if I wanted my thinking to be communicated clearly.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As I've written above, I would have liked a greater proportion of the course to be spent on writing rather than reading and discussions of what we'd read. I loved the "some sentences" practice we did every day and enjoyed other small writing activities that were a part of the course, and found these to be incredibly intellectually stimulating. I have never had another opportunity to think about my own writing (or the writing of others) like that.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings were excellent, and the weekly note-taking assignments made me think more deeply about what I was reading both for this class and for other classes I was taking.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The writing groups were an incredible addition to the class. I appreciated meeting with a group of my colleagues once a week in the second half of the term.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This was really about the same level of intellectual stimulation as all my other courses, but I got something useful out of it at least.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be bold and be vulnerable. Now is the time show blindspots. The course will help you become a better thinker and a better writer!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great class to take at any level of your process, but also great to take as a first-year.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would strongly recommend the course, but might caution that it is an intense experience to have your writing held up under this kind of microscope. Not necessarily a bad thing :)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a writing heavy course that will give you MUCH completed work to look back on. For a graduate student especially, it gave me the time and space and push I needed to get a lot of writing and note-taking done that will use in the future!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take it, especially if you are interested in doctoral work (or any other field of work where writing will matter).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will get inside your brain in ways that can be very challenging but, in the end, so so useful if you let it be.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would absolutely take this course.  It is a lot more work during the semester than other courses because there are many weekly deadlines, but it is totally worth it.  My writing grew immensely, and I am very grateful to have had the opportunity to take this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class changed my life and will continue to change my life as I metabolize all that I've learned this term. Though I wish I had taken it in the first semester of my Ph.D. I think having had the first year to understand the particularities and cadences of a doctoral program made taking it in my second year the best time to do it. Writing is Thinking has made me a better writer, reader, and confident person as it relates to both. Receiving weekly feedback on my writing helped me hone in on my personal writing skills and begin to figure out how to change/adjust them. More than that, this class forced me to confront my anxieties around writing and my fears of being seen as not being good enough. Though neither of those has "gone away" per se, I am now more able to sit with them and take more responsibility for how I sometimes allow them to overwhelm me. Toril seems intimidating, but she is so deeply kind. So kind. Receiving consistent feedback and engagement with your writing and thinking from someone so deeply invested in both is not something that happens even 2% of the time in graduate school. Most people never receive that, and the few who do receive it too late. The class might feel scary, but you will be deeply cared for while not being coddled, and you will grow a lot in the process

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned some biographical details of Antonin Artaud. I learned that painting is writing. I learned that Levinas thinks the woman is a fecund, and voluptuous gate to the male-child.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Derrida's notion of 'play'
- Heidegger, Husserl, Nietzsche, and Freud's influences on Derrida (for lack of a better word, sorry Fred)
-  A very slow reading practice, consulting the original French and interlocutors throughout

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the intellectual and socio-political history of deconstruction pretty well, I'd say. The context(s) in which Derrida was making his interventions were a bit of a blind spot for me prior to the course. Although I knew Derrida was commenting on and critiquing structuralism, I did not understand how this fit into the larger issue of western metaphysics until taking Dr. Reilly's course. I also learned to recognize different moves Derrida makes in his deconstructions. The implementation of the logic of the supplement or the concept of play, for instance. I feel that I now have a confident grasp of these concepts. Derrida's critique of Hegel and the restricted economy also stuck with me, and I will likely return to it and even work on it in the coming years.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Critical thinking. It’s eye-opening for me to learn how Derrida’s approach to deconstruction challenges fixed meanings, hierarchies, and binary oppositions. 
2. Interdisciplinary Connections. Writing and Difference draws on psychoanalysis, linguistics, anthropology, and many other disciplines. For me, I learned how to apply these ideas to novels and use them as a strategy to write my final paper.
3. Close reading and annotating. To better understand theories, it’s important to use highlighting/ underlining/ margin notes on the text. I found it especially helpful to do paper reading in this course, because it requires more attention and thus leads to deeper processing and thinking.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The readings provided an interesting survey of Derrida's thought and the environment of this thought. Course lectures provided organizing schema for the diverse array of readings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Cate has a true gift for describing Derrida's work. It is very common with Derrida lectures/explanations to either oversimplify to the point of gross misrepresentation, or stick so close to the text that students aren't assisted in learning how to read Derrida themselves. Cate falls into neither trap, maintaining necessary complexity while answering student questions with engagement and generosity.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Reilly consistently made sure to address all of our questions about course material. She constantly asked us to ask questions. She kept the course schedule flexible, which allowed us to return to material from weeks prior as needed. This provided a sort of continuity to the course, which assisted in my own understanding of course material. Dr. Reilly also chatted with students during class breaks and after class, donating her time in order to assist us with our questions or with concepts that we may have been struggling with. Her ability to put Derrida's work in context socially and politically as well as philosophically was uniquely helpful. I felt that this facilitated my understanding of course material. Although the seminar style worked well for this course, Dr. Reilly's lectures were of utmost importance. They should be kept at all costs in future semesters, and perhaps even expanded.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Reilly always encourages questions, thoughts and ideas in class. She is approachable outside class, offering brilliant advice during office hours. She is good at what she teaches, and explains complex concepts clearly.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course did not seem to engender thoughtful or engaged discussion. Given that the Professor tried hard to include both structured lecture and class discussion, I think they could have privilged one of these categories more and either committed more to lectures (which were interesting) or demanded more debate in discussion. As it stood, the discussions seemed to be a waste of time.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Cate's lectures, her use of the white board, her enthusiasm, and her intellectual generosity towards students.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was extremely stimulating intellectually in terms of the breadth of Derrida's work. I feel as though I've gotten not only a good handle on Derrida and Deconstruction, but now I also feel prepared to take on the history of phenomenology, structuralism, and psychoanalysis. In this way, the course was stimulating on terms keeping me interested in how Derrida's work connects to several different disciplines/domains or what have you. The course also challenged me to read better, more closely, more carefully, and so on. This is perhaps the strongest way in which I was stimulated, as it provided me with a challenging set of reading practices that I implemented both inside and outside of the classroom.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course encouraged us to question assumptions we often take for granted, such as the stability of meaning. Discussions were especially engaging when we connected Derrida’s theories to broader themes. And Professor Reilly’s knowledge of the subject is unbelievable—she is a truly inspirational professor.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are specifically interested in a particular way of reading texts based on Derrida's reduction of arguments to a narrow set of metaphors then this is perfect.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is centered on "Writing and Difference." If you haven't read it before, look it up and make sure you are committed to spending a semester on it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Ask as many questions as you can. Write them down as you read and as they come to you. Ask your peers and Dr. Reilly during class. Questions move the course forward. Also, give everything a second reading. I can't stress enough. It is nearly impossible to get everything Derrida is doing on one reading. Give yourself enough time in the week to read and reread.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Derrida is not easy to read, so prepare to challenge yourself. But you won’t regret it! The course content is well organized thematically. And Professor Reilly is clever and caring, I wish I could take a class with her again.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: I learned about the intellectual history of psychoanalysis, academic course structure/design, and interdisciplinary methodologies.

response_text: learned a lot about Lacanian psychoanalysis and how it's applied in theory

response_text: I learned a lot of content related to psychoanalysis and theories of subjectification, but I also learned a lot about the cultural, epistemological, and philosophical contexts of those texts. This was stimulating for my own thinking and opened new avenues for me.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Ranjana is a really patient and encouraging teacher, and I appreciated how she took questions seriously and gave thorough, thoughtful answers. She made this challenging and complex topic feel approachable, and I felt able to take from it what I wanted.
