question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment is both rigorous and stimulating, but also calming and welcoming. I enjoyed the instructors broad introductions of the texts alongside her attention to questions and textual content.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I enjoyed reading Freud and Lacan. I also appreciated the snacks, given the time.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Having an exceedingly competent, respectful/compassionate, and intellectually responsible instructor made the course stimulating.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Cool introduction to psychoanalytic theory, very useful if you want to be exposed to it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The Unc. is structured like a language.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You better REALLY like Lacan

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't miss the opportunity to take this or any course with Prof. Khanna.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: After this course, I feel significantly more capable of approaching critical theory with a thorough methodology for deep engagement. I found our "grid" exercise incredibly useful, as well as navigating key questions, concept clusters, and connections to a genealogy of other feminist lit.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I am no longer afraid of the academic monograph
- Class treats improve everything
- Look out for aesthetic saviorism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I became a more attentive reader, more confident in sharing my thoughts, and better at asking questions of both the texts we read and my peers in the graduate seminar room to better understand the theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Feminist Studies Now, and Again set out to trace the (dis)continuities between '70s contemporary feminisms. This framework required that I think meta-discursively; this hadn't been my strength, and I leave the course more confident in my ability to do so. Moreover, Professors Nash and Wiegman modeled how to analyze scholarly methodology, in turn developing my ability to identify a text's argument, intervention, style, and archive. These are vital intellectual skills. That said, the professors' own commitments to investigating field formations and transformations occasionally became repetitive by the semester's end and foreclosed other ways of engaging the material.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a range of critical approaches to feminist texts, such as asking after political vision and attachment, genre, and affect, and aesthetic analysis. I learned how to consider such texts metadiscursively and deepened my understanding of field formation. I gained knowledge of a range of canonical and especially contemporary feminist texts that highlighted sustained areas of debate or conversation and critical habits.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Skepticism of the desire for innocence/purity/to be "outside"; variety and impact of possible forms (e.g., manifesto, academic article or book, play, memoir, etc.); connections between/among past and present

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated that Robyn and Jen started out each class with an introduction to the authors, context for the text, and their own key questions to facilitate discussion. I also appreciated their contributions to our own discussions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The grid, obviously. (In all seriousness, I really appreciated the way Jen and Robyn prepped for class and facilitated discussion.)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciate that we could write a critical engagement with a colleague. This flexibility meant I could dig deeper into a text with someone else before coming to class. Participating in the collaborative exercise before discussing the text in class gave me an extra layer of understanding and helped me develop new questions for the larger seminar conversation. It also mitigated what usually happens in class when people feign understanding because, in the initial conversation, we could be more honest about our engagement with the text and help each other fill in the gaps.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professors Nash and Wiegman began each session by noting the concepts and questions to be considered, which helped structure the discussions. Moreover, the professors' knowledge of and excitement for the materials energized the classroom.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the conversation-based seminar format and would keep the practice of mapping terms/inquiries/etc. I appreciated when one or both professors gave more background/context for particular text(s) in certain classes and would make this more of a convention across classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Instructors' openness and trust in students made class discussions rigorous and thought-provoking

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The thread between each week's texts was incredibly stimulating; each week built off of the previous week so well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The atmosphere of engagement and discussion was stimulating. Both students and professors seemed genuinely interested in what everyone else was thinking, and folks were tuned in to one another, making it easy to tell when someone was thinking, when to invite someone in, etc.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The wide variety of readings made the course stimulating. Although sometimes tedious, submitting the critical engagement throughout the semester and receiving incredibly generous and attentive feedback from the professors meant that I could see myself developing in both my writing and engagement.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Again, I appreciate the course's ambition to think about the development of feminist thought from the Second Wave to the present. This ambition, though, was unrealized. The syllabus did not seem to have a sense of direction, the selection of materials thus felt arbitrary—little justification was offered for the bibliography, and some texts were assigned that the professors hadn't read—, the readings were frequently redundant—and insufficiently representative of contemporary feminist intellectual production. The most convincing unit was "American Grammar," in which we traced the rearticulations of Hortense Spillers's seminal "Mama's Baby, Papa's Maybe" across several monographs.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Active conversation made this class stimulating as well as the topic. Dedicated courses like this in feminist studies are important to thinking through history and the challenges of the present, and this course brought together students from multiple disciplines. Though I understand this is not a foundations course, I would have benefitted from the inclusion of more canonical texts. For instance, the American Grammar section was one of the most stimulating, largely owing to the richness of Mama's Baby, Papa's Maybe and its influence on many other texts.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The students made class discussion particularly stimulating, especially the variety of backgrounds/trainings/knowledge bases and the students' willingness and ability to work hard, ask questions, and think critically

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was the most intellectually rigorous seminar I have taken at Duke, as each week required such deep engagement with each text in order to make the most out of each seminar. It was incredibly rewarding. I am a better scholar for this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Jen and Robyn will challenge you, and you will become a more expansive thinker if you take the readings and conversations seriously. The class is rigorous but not difficult, and by that I mean it will take a lot of time to get through the readings and come to class ready to participate actively. Take it seriously and you will get a lot out of it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is befit for students who research feminist intellectual history. Those who approach feminism with other aims may find its focus on the circulation of feminist discourse limiting. I nevertheless appreciate that Duke offers classes like this, and I encourage the University to continue to support advanced feminist inquiry.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I wholeheartedly recommend taking an advanced, contemporary-forward feminist studies course like this for students from any discipline interested in women's studies, gender and sexuality studies, queer and trans studies, and critical race studies.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Imaginative thinking, close reading, and writing a close reading paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My close reading got a lot better than I thought it could. It seemed that after our first exercise the door had been opened for more intense and thoughtful consideration of Woolf's texts. I had read some of Woolf prior to the class, but the structure of reading was a little fast paced. In high school, I think we read Mrs. Dalloway in a week and a half. This made it difficult to spend serious time analyzing the writing and the characters and everything that the book has to offer (which is endless). With Dr. Kronfeld, I was able to read Woolf's texts with more time and appreciation. This made me a better analyst and a more empathetic one as well. Dr. Kronfeld encourages critique and honest opinions but also emphasizes analyzing people and characters with an empathetic lens, as it leads to fuller understanding. This is demonstrated both in the works chosen and the ways they were discussed. I'm not sure if I've described three specific things, but it is difficult to quantify how valuable this course has been to me in my first semester. While I am a STEM major, I think it's important to engage our minds and souls with literature. This class is a great way to do that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We were taught the basics of close reading, how to connect literature to philosophical ideas, and we learned about use of narratology as a literary device.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, analysis, reading between the lines

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned a lot about Virginia Woolf's various works and how to analyze them. Through several close reading writing assignments, I honed my ability to deeply analyze Woolf's works and put to use my newfound understanding of how to analyze literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to close read, how to analyze texts, and how to write a critical literature essay. I also learned about the intersection of literature and philosophy through Woolf's texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned a lot about how to perform close reading and how to dissect Virginia Woolf's writing. I also discovered a new way to write an analytical paper without it being hyper-structured and argumentative but simply analyzing the work. Lastly, I was able to get used to the caliber of material and quantity of material that literature/writing classes have in college.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel like asking and answering questions that further help my understanding and learning the complexities of some things. In this class, asking the right questions plays a huge role in how you can receive help and challenge your thinking in terms of finding the answer you need.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned a lot about 20th century literature, movements, and philosophical ideas. I feel like this course helped me develop critical thinking skills, as well as strengthened by ability to carefully and assess literature. Finally, I think this class provided a lot of insight into perspective and different ways of viewing the world through assessing writing, which I think I will carry with me outside of this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to separate a text into its stylistic and literary components (syntax, diction, rhetorical devices, stream of consciousness, POV, etc.), reason how these choices add or detract from an author's main message behind the text, and compare texts from different works with one another.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Kronfeld was engaging and clearly passionate for her work/the topics of the class. She kept a schedule for the readings and stuck to it, which gave the classes structure.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the small group discussions. At the beginning of the year, participating seemed a bit intimidating - though we all quickly warmed to eachother and became comfortable. The small groups make discussion easier and more free because you don't have to think of a polished answer or question. Not a structure but I liked how open and encouraging everyone in the class was of alternative ideas. It wasn't that any interpretation was permissible, but the class recognized the living nature of meaning in the works which was dope. I like the short papers of analysis but I honestly found myself running out of room. Having spoken to other students, they faced similar issues. I think a page minimum is fine but maybe no maximum would be great so that I could write more. I like the interdisciplinary focus like showing the themes through music, art, and literature.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Kronfeld did a really good job of giving us entry-point ideas to build our understanding of the texts from the ground up, leading us to develop complex ideas based on the texts. I appreciated the openness of discussions and felt that by the end of the semester I became comfortable with my classmates. Additionally, I really appreciated the approach she took to the papers. She was very constructive with her feedback and emphasized the importance of an organic writing process, in which we were able to explore different writing styles and try new things. This was the first class for which I've ever enjoyed writing a paper.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think all of it was productive, I especially liked going to the library to see Virginia Woolf's desk

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof K did a really nice job of mixing lecturing with class participation. While she spend a significant amount of time (especially at the beginning of the semester) introducing new vocabulary and literary techniques via lectures, she also made an effort to keep our class engaged throughout the term by incorporating group presentations, and frequent peer review sessions into class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Kronfeld is such a spectacular professor, I loved how she made complex and challenging intellectual ideas easier to understand but didn't dumb anything down.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Kronfeld struck a really great balance, especially in the second half of the course, of allowing us to guide discussions and pointing us toward passages or topics that are traditionally considered important. She also did a fantastic job of teaching close reading techniques in an easy-to-understand way, and also taught us how to connect said techniques to the meaning of the work on a broader scale.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Good questions being asked, and having open discussions and creating an environment where asking questions no matter how dumb WE think it is because it sparks learning

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Kronfeld was an incredible facilitator of this class. She was extremely knowledgable of Woolf, but also was able to teach us about things related to Woolf, like philosophical terms and literary techniques. I really enjoyed the way this class was structured, and I looked forward to coming to class each week. I would not change how this class is structured (i.e. the chronological order of the novels) as I think that the way we went through the readings gave me a really unique perspective on Virginia Woolf's work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Being assigned readings throughout the week and then discussing them during class was very helpful because it allowed me to dig deep within the text, especially on literary choices that were confusing or ambiguous. I also liked the way that office hours were set up, since we could just go to them right after class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The topics were really interesting and the way Dr. Kronfeld led the class was engaging and fun since it differed from a high school literature class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Everyone cared and so it was fun.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Thinking about the ways in which literature conveys perceptive processes was very stimulating. Virginia Woolf's writing is extremely stimulating, and examining her techniques in conversation with philosophical texts was extremely stimulating and allowed me to develop the way in which I view the world.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The expectation that everyone share their perspectives and ideas. By encouraging everyone to participate, Prof K. made it clear from the start that this classroom was a space for everyone to contribute and to ask questions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was extremely intellectually stimulating due to the great balance of both lecture and class discussion.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course material, first of all, is super engaging if it's something you're interested in. Because we were able to hone in on Virginia Woolf and her specific works and techniques, we were able to become very familiar with her thoughts and philosophies. The difficulty of Woolf's novels also adds to the class because it challenged me to focus in for the reading assignments and annotate, which isn't something I have historically done.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Again, our professor would stimulate our learning not only through asking questions but also teaching us new terminology as well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think this class was intellectually stimulating for me because it challenged me to think in new ways. As someone who gravitates towards STEM, I felt like reading these novels and discussing their form and content helped me to work a different part of my brain than I use in my other classes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The texts were relatively difficult to comprehend at first, since Woolf's writing style is different from most texts assigned in high school. However, after a while, you get better at deeply analyzing Woolf's literary choices, allowing you to understand the underlying reasons why she uses the techniques that she does.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's fun but a decent amount of work. Reading is important.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In the course, I developed critical thinking skills when examining labels and concepts like Latino and Latinidad. I learned about the history of the Latinx community in the United States and gained insight into issues like discrimination and assimilation that followed mass migration. I learned about the relevance of music in Latinx culture and thought about the many ways it can be used to express and explore culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Coming into the class, I had some pretty big assumptions about the general content of the class. At first, I didn't think the course was going to center on US Latinx studies; I thought it was
going to focus on the history of Latin American countries and how those become affected by US intervention. Personally, I truly enjoy the direction the course is going. Learning about the history
of Latinos in the US, their struggles, their legacy, is a rich topic that I had previously not had the resources to understand. I've always wanted to learn more about this but I've never really had
the impetus to do so. I think it is so interesting to talk about these historical events, like the Chicano movement or the labor strikes, and tell my friends about them. It's a part of history that
goes unnoticed and it's worthy of bringing up everyone once in a while during a conversation. Outside of that, I feel like this class has made me more conscious of the continual Latino
presence in the US and what people are doing to combat injustice. I've done research and learned about powerful organizations, both in North Carolina and my hometown of Miami. It's
amazing seeing that everywhere there are communities like these all fighting for visibility and justice. I gain a lot from the music component of the course, and connect it to other music classes I've
taken at Duke. It's interesting seeing the connection between how the music we study is composed and what the music is representing. Understanding the Chicano movement through
song is a beautiful way to look at history. A song I particularly found touching was "Urbano's song". It was by far one of the saddest songs I've heard this year, and I still listen to it in my
 spare time.More concisely I learned:
- How to analyze Latino history and research topics in Latino studies.
- How to make a community facing project 
- How service learning can be used to supplement a class as well as engage with the surrounding community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Themes of Russian literature, how to analyze Russian prose, evolution of literary works in Russia throughout 20th and 21st centuries.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: history of russian literature, aspects of russian identity as it pertains to the great patriotic war, and the social and political context of the soviet union

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: creative writing, analyzing literary pieces

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned about the internal structure and meaning of individual stories while tracing the historical development of Russian prose within shifting political and cultural contexts. I explored how identity is shaped, contested, and expressed in these artistic works. Complementing the readings, I engaged with acclaimed Russian films, comparing how key themes and identities are portrayed differently in cinematic versus written narratives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The most importqnt theme of the course was HOW Russians coped with dramatic change. Many of the texts delved into personal histories of tough times throughout Russian history specifically during and after the fall fo the soviet union.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways to analyze 1900s-2000s Russian media in translation, how to access many of these sources, and general themes of this media!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better ability to analyze literature and film, and I am able to do so within specific cultural context. I have also improved my reading and presentation skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three things that I learned in this course are how to analyze and explore texts, greater understand the context of the texts/films and how that plays a role, and explore major themes and symbolism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Contextualizing works of literature by examining how they connect to their literary period (and to the periods preceding/after), discovering the purpose of characters and plot points.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Generally, I learned more about Russian history and the influence historical events had on the development of literature from the Twentieth Century up until now. This includes how at the beginning of the Twentieth Century, there was an air of anticipation for the revolution, but also generally for change with the government as well as social and material circumstances. I learned how within literature there was a period of experimentation where art forms were being mixed together and explored different themes such as gay and lesbian relationships, as well as the position of women in society. I also learned about the labor camps people were sent to that were in places with extreme weather, or where everyone would most certainly die either from the conditions or at the hands of the guards.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned more about contemporary Russian film and literature, especially those that have become prominent in the last few years.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much in this course.  I learned how to contextualize art and cultural products within the broader context of their creation, and reason about how things ranging from changing social norms and gender roles, to dictatorial censorship impacted the works produced under those circumstances.  I also learned how to find scholarly sources and incorporate them into my writing to support my arguments,  a skill that will undoubtedly serve me in my future endeavors as a student, writer, and intellectual.  I also learned how to analyze art and uncover nuance within visual language.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is really not much work, but be prepared for really vague assignments, especially for the papers. The only real "guidelines" for the papers were in the syllabus, and that was just to tell you how long the paper should be. Papers are "open to interpretation", but it can be hard to know what exactly he wants. It would also help to just speak to him directly, as he is really a very kind professor. The big papers can just be a little daunting when you're not sure what to write about. Other than that though, great course, I would reccomend.
